number of helpful: 122 of 128 people (95%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Enjoy musical immersion like no other as your favorite artists attempt to murder you.Beat Hazard is one of the better bullet hell space shooters I've played, with fluid controls that really need no explanation. Jumping right in, you'll probably die horribly right out of the gate, but the game has a perk and progression feature that allows you to enhance your abilities as you go along.There are also in-game power-ups, which enhance the ever-important score multiplier, upgrade your weapons, and give you lovely bombs to destroy entire screens of swarming enemy ships. There's even a power-up that will increase the volume of the music you select.And that, the music, is the real draw of games like this, that depends on your personal investment with your music library to add an additional level of investment on the part of the player. While this may feel somewhat emotionally manipulative at times, I'm not going to knock the game for tricking me into enjoying it.Levels seem to match up to the music you're playing if you squint a bit. There's also a photosensitive seizure warning included at the start of the game, and with all the bright flashing colors and neon streaks of light firing everywhere, that's an appropriate warning. The visuals themselves may not be to your personal taste, though they're executed well, with a decent variety of different enemy types to shoot down.Ultimately, Beat Hazard fulfills a need I didn't even know I had; the need to murder waves of enemies while Sara Bareilles croons at me to say I'm sorry for what I've done. I'm sorry, okay? I'm so sorry. Please stop sending these giant worm monsters after me.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Beat Hazard (along with the DLC) is one of the few games that I fully appreciate. It's definitely up there as far as quality twin-stick shooters go. There are just so many things that make this game good.Play your own music - This was the very first 'play your own music' game that I got on Steam. It's not the most special feature on Beat Hazard but it's the main reason I enjoyed it as a twin-stick shooter. I don't have a lot of experience in the genre so being able to play on my own pace depending on the song used was a major positive factor for me.Difficulty Adjustment - The difficulty is easily adjustable in a multitude of ways. You have your conventional difficulty settings (easy, etc, etc). Then you have visual intensity which to me is somewhat of a visual handicap (with benefits of course). Two other ways to adjust difficulty would be by picking songs with varied intensities or by playing with the new DLC content which adds ship customization complete with stats. In a game with this many options, it won't matter what skill level you are within the genre. It's still very possible to feel a small sense of accomplishment even as a casual player.Music Discovery - In this day and age, I no longer listen to the radio unless I'm really bored while driving from location A to B. Beat Hazard allows you to play while listening to various radio stations (custom or default added). In all honesty, I have discovered a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of music during the few months that I have been really into Beat Hazard.There's a lot more things that make Beat Hazard a wonderful game. For the sake of simplicity, I merely listed 3 of my favorite reasons.10/10It's nearly impossible to get bored in this game.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												This game is freakin' addictive. When you combine twin-stick shooter mechanics with intense music-driven gameplay, you get Beat Hazard. Everything from the explosions to the type of enemies you encounter are all affected by the beat of the music. There's more to it as well. You can collect power-ups, get multipliers to increase your score and, of course, you can use your own music (You have to buy iTunes support, but it's only a dollar, so literally a small price to pay). You can also rank up and get perks that can give you a leg-up to shooting up the leaderboards. And then there's the DLC (Ultra and Shadow Operations) which add new ships, enemies, missions (getting [x] amount of points or completing [x] amount of songs on a certain difficulty) and even Steam Workshop support, letting you download even more ships and missions. Pausing's a little weird, however; with an Xbox 360 controller you have to press both Start and Back to pause. Other than that, this is easily one of the best music-driven games I've played. If you're tired of Audiosurf and want something different, this is for you.A word of warning, however: There are LOTS of flashing lights and visuals in this game (it even warns you when you start the game). So if you suffer for photosensitive seizures or the like, then you should avoid this game (Then again, if you suffer from such a condition, you shouldn't be playing games in the first place).

number of helpful: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												I have played Audiosurf for a long time and I was not sure if Beat Hazard was a game that could stand out for me as a music-based game. I finally decided to give Beat Hazard a try after it was available for several years on the market. It feels like a game inspired by the classic game Asteroids, but with songs from your music library playing while you control your spaceship. So the basic premise of the game is you maneuvering a spaceship while avoiding asteroids and many enemy spaceships of varying types and sizes. There are many games of this genre in a crowded market, but Beat Hazard carves out its own identity with its challenging action and allows you to take on numerous enemies and other hazards as you enjoy the rhythm of the songs of your favorite artists and built-in songs.There had been criticism of Beat Hazard because of the lack of iTunes support. I strongly recommend buying the related Beat Hazard DLC that supports iTunes songs. I played songs from iTunes and they work just fine. The game accepts all song file types with the exception of CDs, so you will have to rip the CDs in order to play the songs. Another criticism had been that Beat Hazard doesn’t seem exciting enough on slow songs. I played many slow songs, including some pop/soft rock songs, and there is enough intensity in the visuals and the mayhem to make the gameplay exciting. It is beautiful to see your spaceship’s bright neon fire fill the screen while the explosions are so vibrant. There are times when the brightness of the visuals is a bit overdone, especially as the track progresses. When the visuals are too intense it can feel uncomfortable for those with sensitive eyes. Therefore, it would be best to take a break from the action if the flashing strobe feels overwhelming.There are several gameplay modes in the game and many spaceships to choose from. The standard mode requires you to play through an entire track until it is finished. Survival mode requires you to last as long as possible while trying to play through an entire album. The spaceships have their own specific missions such as accumulating a minimum number of points without getting the death penalty that would nullify some or all of the points you had scored previously. These specific missions for spaceships add to the challenge of playing this old-school shooter while enjoying the rhythm of whatever song you are playing. There is a boss rush mode that requires you to defeat wave after wave of bosses until you have no more lives remaining. The bosses become familiar after experiencing the standard modes since bosses appear at specific points of the song. These modes are exciting in their own way, but it feels like there aren’t too many other modes to further increase replay value. However, there is online play that allows you to play the various modes with a friend. The bottom of the screen adds a nice touch to the game by notifying you of your progress, your friends’ progress, and other players who are looking to playing with others.You can level up in the game and that happens as you progress through each track. After leveling up enough you will earn a new rank and you can see how you rank against other players on the global leaderboard. There is no leaderboard for individual songs like Audiosurf, but Beat Hazard’s way of leveling up provides a sense of progression. I played with the mouse and keyboard setup and it plays quite well. There is the option of playing with a controller.There are many powerups in the game. As you pick up volume and power powerups, your spaceship’s lasers become increasingly powerful, but the gameplay will also intensify. The screen fills up with a large number of small enemy spaceships and large spaceships to balance the gameplay and keep you from being significantly overpowered.I think Beat Hazard is a fun game that some players may find old after playing through their favorite tracks in all the available modes. However, this game is definitely worth the $9.99 purchase price plus the DLCs. You can’t go wrong with game that offers enough replay value that is as large as your music collection, vibrant visuals, intense boss battles, and lots of powerups.My Score: 7.5/10

												Love old school shooters like asteroids where all the action takes place on one screen,then you will REALLY like this one.Start playing and you realise that when you play your own tracks the ebb and flow that the game follows behaves differently every time.As you play and blow up more ships you get power ups such as bombs,more fire power ect,but i found myself heading straight for the "VOLUME UP" power up as soon as it appeared.Now i know exactally why this is,you get to play to your own music and boy oh boy it makes the game all the better for it.Finding yourself listening along to your favoriote songs and completely anihilating the enemy is rather exiting and extremely entertaining to the point that you just want to play along to your own music.The graphics and adequate for this type of game,there is no story at all (DOESNT NEED ONE) but its the music that will keep you playing as you destroy things to the sound of your own music and its that-that will cause you to become addicted to this simple yet great little shooter.Would reccomend to anyone that wants to shoot things and blow stuff up to their own music if thats not you then i wouldent buy this game,if it is welcome to the "SOUNDS OF YOUR OWN DESTRUCTION" (well it will feel that way when you get outnumbered and die enough anyway).

content:
Posted: March 6, 2013
												Beat Hazard is a top down dual stick arcade shooter similar to the classic game Asteroid, but on neon colored steroids. Its pretty much contained in a single screen and the game throws waves of asteroids, ships and space worms after you. Since its a dual stick shooter, the controls are easy, left stick to move, right stick to fire the direction you're aiming. There are also bombs to clear the screen when it gets completely full of enemies. Beat Hazard has a major twist. Your rate of fire is controlled by the tempo or beats per minute of the music. Not just your bullets but the enemy speed too. If you don't care for the songs that the game comes with, you can play one of your own .mp3s or listen to Internet radio. The neon laser beams make the game come to life as more than a game. It could be a visualizer for your mp3 playlist.Every song is a level. When the song ends or your lives run out, you see your high score and the game remembers how far you got and your high score. So you can play it again for a better high score or to go further in the song. I'd much rather have the game go from song to song than force me to start up a new game for the next song. There is a survival mode that will keep going song to song, but its just a single life.The enemy diversity shines through in the game. There are simple ships that fly in long waves. Larger ships that take more damage. Even larger ships that explode into a hail of homing missiles. Still other ships have dual repulsor beams to push you around. Magnetic ships have dual rays that pull you in. There are segmented space worms, easier to defeat neon worms. It is a varitable feast. Not just that, but diverse bosses. Everything from huge space ships, gigantic worms to star fish that coil up their tentacles for protection. These enemies will fill your screen in no time especially on the upper three difficulties. The game has a way to keep your mind engaged as to how you can survive.Every score that you have go to your level or rank. The score is like experience. You will rank up and get to unlock a perk. You need to buy the perk once its been unlocked. Not just buy it, but buy multiples of it. Then equip it. There are perks that give you extra lives, extra bombs, and increase score multipliers. Other things that can get unlocked are extra difficulty modes for when 'hardcore' gets too easy for you.There are other layers of complexity to the Beat Hazard such as a risk reward system. If you don't shoot a set amount of time your score multiplier goes up. If you survive long enough without dying, the multiplier goes up again. Before you know it you're at 45+ of a score multiplier if not 100+ with perks. All the while enemies will drop things for you to pickup such as extra multipliers, money, bombs to use, power ups for your laser and volume increases. Its very risk or reward. Do you leave your safe corner of the screen, navigate through the madness to get your $10?The game is kind enough that when you die, it litters the area with items to get you back up and competing again. That is a downfall of other games that if you die late into a game, your underpowered ship is useless against the high difficulty enemies.If you get lonely there is 2 player and online multiplayer where you compete on a single screen against someone. Not just that, but the game will notify you if someone is trying to multiplayer at that time. You can interrupt your own game to play against someone. This ensures there's always someone to play.I say this game is well worth the $10 asking price.

												Want to interact with your music?Want to fly around and shoot things in space?Want to get a seizure and/or a migraine in just thirty seconds or less?Look no further."Bullet Hell" themes are heavily layered on top of this shoot-em-up game, so if you are into constant panic and you have quick reflexes and good observation skills, this game will be just perfect for you.I will be blunt with this next part. If you are epileptic or if bright and rapidly-flashing lights have any sort of negative effect on you, for the love of all that is pure, PLEASE stay the ♥♥♥♥ away from this game. There is almost never a single moment in the gameplay where some part of the screen is not rapidly flashing and changing colors. Luckily, I am not sensitive to rapid flashes or anything like that. But, seeing as how this explosion of lights and color was enough to make my left eye burn to the point of watering over and hurting really badly after playing through just two different songs, it will tear a [flashing] light-sensitive person to shreds in just a matter of seconds. Play carefully, people.I give this fever dream a 10/10.

												I'm a little surprised I havent already reviewed this game, but simply put, this is one amazing gaming experience. Think of asteroids with modern graphics and visuals. number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												Beat Hazard is one of my favorite games on Steam.  I've always been interested in the idea of music modifying a game to produce a game where you feel like you play your music. And honestly... Beat Hazard isn't that game.  It suffer the same fate as all these procedurally generated music games, like Audiosurf, where the music doesn't have a strong connection to the game you're playing.  When you play Beat Hazard, there is limited connectability to the the music. The Music in Beat Hazard pretty much affects the "intensity" of the game.   If you play some music with a high BPM enemies will move at a faster rate than a low BPM.  But even playing Happy Hardcore and other fast BPM music, the game doesn't appear broken, which is a good thing.  A VERY good thing, as I'd hate to see the game limit what types of music it can play. In addition, the game comes with a built in soundtrack, something Audiosurf doesn't really do, so at least you can play exactly what song the developer was thinking of when you play the game, and the fact is... it works and by that I mean very well.  There a variety of songs chosen but slow songs have a different feel from fast songs.  That's good. But you'll play through the 20 songs or so and then you'll have to play your music?  Right?    Well... not unless you want to, though you can.  There's also internet radio!   At least my copy (which is from the original launch) came with a few stations already set up and adding more is relatively easy, EXCEPT it requires editing a file, so steam boxes and anyone playing in a big picture mode has to go through a few hoops to make it work.  It's not awful, but it's an annoying few steps that I wish wasn't required. However the build in internet radio works, and works well, rather than "play a song" you instead play a time battle, 4 minutes up to 20 minutes I believe (and a survival mode for when you want to see how far you can go).  And again, it's YOUR choice.  I chose an electronica station, so I was loving the music and the game, and it worked... really well.   Well except for the fact there's a little disconnect between the game and the song, but you can use internet radio, and listen to great music as you play.So what's the game like?  It's a bit like Geometry wars.  Rather than fighting geometry shapes, you're instead blasting ships and flying dodging their attacks.  It's quite similar to bullet hell games, but there's a few major changes.  First the game isn't that brutally hard, and gives you multiple difficulty options (including a few you can only unlock through a perk system).  Second, there's power ups.  Enemy ships when destroyed can drop different items, some of them are for points, some of them are weapons you can trigger, and finally there's "volume" and "power".  Power does exactly what you think, it makes your ship strong, however Volume is different.  It increases the sound of the song you're listening to.  At the beginning your music is quite, but as you volume up the sound increases so you can hear your song at full volume.  This also affects the power of your ship (I think defensively) and when you max both you get a special mode, so both of these power ups are important. While that disconnect from the music for the game doesn't make this the game I dream of, the fact is the gameplay of the game is fun, and there's a decent connection when you're listening to music and what's happening in the game.  If a song goes from slow to fast and back, you'll notice enemies speeding up and slowing down.  The connection could be better, if you play a song two or three times, it's random how enemies will appear and attack.   However the gameplay itself is solid, and you are able to listen to music you like and have it make a minor effect on the game you're playing. But the game underneath is just a fun game.  I love geometry wars, and Beat Hazard I think might actually beat Geometry wars for replayability.  I recommend this game not because it's a stunning success in the world of music games, but because it's a fantastic twin stick shooter with a lot of depth.  The two DLCs (Shadow Operations Unit and Ultra) are both excellent add ons, and being able to get the whole set for under 20 bucks is a good value.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I love this game, it combines two things I've always had a passion for, music and games. This is a space shooter that depends on the beats of your own songs. The enemies and your wepoans are either faster and stronger or slower and weaker completely dependng on the song you're playing. If you like dance / eletronic music you'll probably have a harder time playing it! I've had this on the Playstation 3 system and now own it on Steam, so it's safe to say I have around 50 hours in this. I can only write about Beat Hazard Ultra, because I've only played that version so far. The Ultra DLC adds perks and weapons in which you can upgrade using in-game cash. Honestly, Beat Hazard must feel boring without the Ultra DLC, it breathes new life into the game, a damn good one!Every DLC so far has not disappointed me (although there's only two o far), It just feels like a much better game if you have all the DLCs. Both will give you challenges and a ton of stuff to do. The new Shadow Operations Unit is also a great addition, introducing new ships and the ability of creating your own! Each ship will give you 3 challenges, in which some are actually pretty hard to complete! :DBeat Hazard is the game I'll always go back to it sometime because I'll miss its craziness and how good it feels to destroy enemy spaceships. It always feels different because everytime I go back to it, my musical taste has slightly changed. This game is cheap, and if you love music I think you'll like this game too, but be sure to, at least, get hte Ultra DLC, it will be a totally different experience. Beat Hazard (Ultra + Shadow Operations DLC) is an 8.5/10 for me, considering it an indie game and how cheap you can get it, the amount of hours you'll play this will surely not be wasted. :D

content:
Posted: February 2
												After playing like 4 hours of this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T, I a humble gamer, also another blinded(literally) person, wanted to write a review! So, "What is Beat Hazard?". Beat Hazard is an action/arcade game where you need to blow up♥♥♥♥♥♥tons of enemy spaceships while maintaining your tiny♥♥♥♥♥ships "one-hit KO" HP. Sounds fun right? ...Right?OK. It might not be appealing at first sight but once you buy(or get) it and boot up the game, you'll find that you are going to need to move all your music to an easily accessible place. Because Beat Hazards file browser SUCKS! I kid you not, it really does. But worry not my friend who still has his/her eyesight, because once you get the hang of it, you will easily pick the song you want and start sending those spaceships to space junkyard, I guess.Alright, we booted up the game. Closed the game. Moved every piece of music we have in our PC to a better place. Opened up the game again. Picked the song. Now what? Now it's the time to have fun! Simply click anywhere to shoot while using WASD(Honestly I don't remember if I changed the key bindings so go check your settings before hopping into the game.) to move around. You might find that the power of your weapons, as well as the speed of the game, is dependent on the music that is currently playing. Ehem... BEAT HazardWhile playing the game you will die a lot, but don't rage you'll learn to dodge while slowly turning your loyal eyeballs into fried cheeseballs. No one said there is no price but if you really want to see for 2 more days go ahead and turn down the intensity of effects. Actually turn down the intensity because when you max it out(200% is the max value) like I did. You can't see♥♥♥♥♥♥ there will be literally too much ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on your screen. Enemies, FAKIN ASTEROIDS, You and last but not least bullets(or Danmaku 弾幕 if you prefer the original usage or you are a weeaboo like me). Let us start with the enemies, there are 6 type of enemies listed by their difficulty to take down;•Small grey ships, their duty is being as annoying as they can be while trying to flank and kamikaze you.•Medium sized red decalled white ships, their duty is sometimes shooting and sometimes trying to kamikaze you.•Big blue ships, their duty is shooting Homing Yellow Danmaku which can be destroyed if shot upon.•Armada(that's what I call them), their duty is coming in sizes of 20+ and cover the whole screen while shooting at you at once from all sides.•Boss, not much to say simple boss just shoot its weak points.•Twin Boss, little brothers of the Boss.About the asteroids in the game, what they are known for is getting in your way of having fun. Whether they spawn in the middle of the most epicest guitar solo of all times or bump into your ship in the most unsuspecting time. You won't expect it because you are going to be dealing with 513 enemies at once. ♥♥♥♥ ASTEROIDSNow let's talk about how the game uses your music to spawn enemies. Based on my observations the bassier the sound is the more action you'll get. I think the best example would be Orion from Metallica. There is a bass passage in the beginning of the song. This makes the game think "IT'S SHOWTIME BABY" and you'll end up getting your face melted before the song even started. Orion is the hardest song I have ever played in this game. Considering the piece is 8 minutes long with almost 4 minutes of bass solo. This means 4 minutes of non-stop action. My biggest disappointment was the system almost only takes bass as a measure. I personally enjoy listening to Power Metal, a genre which doesn't prioritise bass over treble. That's what you'll get FAKIN ASTEROIDS IN YOUR FAKIN GUITAR SOLOThe game is overall great and fun to play with lots of replayability. You can basically play until you run out of music if that's ever going to happen. The downside is you need to be relaxed and very careful like you are going to beat the world record of being careful to spot every little annoying pieces of ♥♥♥♥s Small grey ships and all the Danmaku while there is literally ♥♥♥♥♥torm happening in your poor screen. I rate this game 8/10 but this doesn't mean it's bad. This game is super cool and fun. Go grab it!

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												[WARNING] NOT FOR PEOPLE WITH EPILEPSY CONDITIONS NOR THOSE SENSITIVE TO STROBBING AND FLASHING LIGHTS! WHILE YOU CAN REDUCE THE INTENSITY IN THE SETTINGS IT IS STILL WAY LARGER THAN THE NORMAL AMOUNT![WARNING]TL;DR: Spaceship, meets star arena meet asteroid with your music providing the tempo for the weapons and enemies! Enjoyable for those who like to challenge themselves since the INSANE difficiulity is definitely insane!Review Starts HereWhat is Beat Hazard?Beat hazard is a 2D top down space shooter game in the veins of asteroid except you have enemies and boss fights. Pretty darn awesome. You have to supply it with your music though. 1:GraphicsNotice the [WARNING] thing above? well not kidding. Each effects is the same as a single flashbang and every shots and explosion from either you or the enemy will sear the screen as bright as the sun causing temperorary blindness and mania in the affected gamers. God forbid you crank up the effect to 200% like i did and played for 30 min straight.The actual graphics themselves are very good as far as 2D spaceshooting game is concern. Sprite move, shoot and explode brilliantly when they die. Meanwhile the 3D effects zoom across the screen blinding you with their colourful effects. And they are bright.2: SoundShooting sounds good, explosive sounds good. For anything else music, you supply it yourself.3:GameplayYou get 2 meter, power and volume meter, collecting powerup increases either the bar game which in turn either increases your shot power or shot intensity respectively. Mostly you want the intensity though because depending on the music the AI can really prove to be a challenge with them swarming you on all side so breaking through will definitely help more.At the start of the game you are provided with 3 bombs that clear HALF the map of enemies and not the whole map. If you die a bomb would automatically be used should one be in your possesion. Perks can be purchase with cash you collect as you destroy craft but only a limited number can be activated at time, they provide in game benefits when you activate them. As you play along the game sometimes boss can appear, these hulking monstrosity often has a gimmick behind thier sleeves that can prove to be rather challenging if you are terrible with them but killing them often provides money and powerups.The game will continue till the song ends so if you pick a long and beaty song at hard or above, prepare for a beating.4:Beat Hazard Ultra DLCCurrently there are 2 version on sale on steam, the normal edition and the one bundled with the DLC Beat Hazard Ultra. Genrally speaking, get the bundle. it includes even more bosses, more enemy types, more perk and generally more of everything that the classic beat hazard doesnt have! Also the effects are shinier in the DLC so yeah, poor retina.Conclusion.Great game with friends or by yourself. hopefully drunken friends that way you can play those super weird music as you blast spaceship in tune to the beat. Definitely a thumbs up.[TIPS]Cant find a hard enough music? Insane too easy? Go use white noises as the music. Dont say i didnt warn you.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator GroupCheck out the Original Network Groups. content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Before reading: this review is about Beat Hazard Ultra, meaning the basic game + dlc. While I still recommend Beat Hazard on its own, it is more simplistic and lacks online co-op that the Ultra version provides, so I strongly recommend this game to be played with DLC.Beat Hazard Ultra is a fast paced space shoot'em up with bright colorful graphics. At first sight it does not look like much, however it has several features that have made it one of the most pleasant surprises in my library. The graphics look amazing at first, they tend to tire out your eyes pretty easily however, so it is not recommended to play for long sessions. There is an option to scale them up (!) or down inside the game menu though.The battle is fluid despite the abundance of color, enemies and the genral chaos that takes place on your screen especially on the higher difficulties. I have even played this on a linux netbook -yes it plays on linux and mac as well- with minimal capabilities and I was honestly surprised at its smoothness. Gameplay is fluid as well, regardless if you are playing with a controller or a mouse and keyboard. In fact, I even find myself preferring the mouse and keyboard mostly because the mouse provides more precise aiming than thumbsticks. The difficulty curve is just right, meaning you can choose from 5 different difficulty settings (easy, normal, hardcore, insane, suicidal) and play in whatever mode you feel comfortable with. This makes the game equally enjoyable for both hardcore shmup players as well as people who are new to the genre, or not particularly skilled. There is also a nice "perk" system implemented, where you can buy upgrades, such as a few special attacks, more multipliers, etc.Music is an integral part of playing the game and your ship's power as well as enemies generated depend on the music you are playing. This means that the exact same level will be generated when you play the exact same track. When the music gets more aggressive, so will your ship's lasers, but that will also make your enemies spawn and move faster. The opposite happens when the music gets mellow. This makes the game quite interesting since it doesn't exactly mean it gets easier on mellow music or harder on heavier music, but instead it manages very successfully to keep the game balanced on either setting so you can have a go on different tracks depending on your mood. The games build in track list is fairly pleasant to play, but why limit yourself there, when you can actually index and play any song in your computer or just play listening to your favorite radio station?What usually disappoints in this genre is the lack of online co-op mode. Well, Beat Hazard Ultra actually HAS online co-op as well as online versus mode where you can easily invite someone over your steam friend list and play together. You can even play listening to the radio, or play your own music as well, provided both of the participants have the same track indexed.To sum it up, if you like shmups or are just curious about the genre, you will definitely enjoy this game. For me, it is a small gem in my library, so I hope more people will discover it in the future.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												To give you an accurate impression of the Beat Hazard experience...I'm going to describe my morning.When I woke up today I discovered that I had nothing to eat for breakfast. All I had was a tub of whey protein. The directions say to mix the whey with milk, water, or "your favorite beverage". I didn't have any milk and water is for weenies so I used Dr. Pepper. It was disastrous, the tiniest sip nearly caused me to throw up. So I dumped all that crap out and settled for a Rolling Rock and a few cookies. In other words: Beat Hazard is what you make of it.This is a treadmill-based twin-stick shooter. The idea is that as you play, the game will continually feed you unlockables and upgrades. It's all part of the process that keeps you on that treadmill. The entertainment typically comes from dodging enemies, their projectiles, and destroying them with a fully-loaded arsenal. Naturally this is a simplistic affair, but what keeps Beat Hazard interesting is the soundtrack. Pick a song, any song, and it'll work with the game. Even on the hardest difficulty, surviving usually isn't too difficult. Getting a high-score on the other hand can be interesting. Aside from the work necessary to unlock all of the score-based multiplier bonuses, you might also have to consider finding that perfect song. This song must be consistently intense, so that enemies spawn constantly, and not have any time-wasting lulls. I suppose a five-minute recording of a dozen jackhammers would suffice, but I don't play for score. Regardless, the meta-game is a unique experiment. It makes you feel like playing to the best of your ability isn't enough to hit the top of the leaderboards, you also have to seek out whatever music other people listen to to reach those hi-scores.Speaking for myself, Beat Hazard is the game I play when I don't have anything better to do. Admittedly, I have a backlog that consists of hundreds of videogames, but... anyway. The point is that I can turn this game on, burn through a few songs, and feel like I've made some progress. I can also pretend that I'm playing a rhythm game that I actually like, one where I can focus on destroying an armada of warships, not press random buttons to the beat. If I could make one complaint, it would be the lack of an option to drop the visual intensity to 25% or lower. The options only allow for down to 50%, which is still a little too much for my eyes. 90% of my deaths can be attributed to losing track of what's going on. Normally this would be a death sentence for a game, but well..I guess it makes sense for Beat Hazard. The more intense the track, the more intense the visuals and subsequent dangers that come with it. If you can't take the heat, get out of the kitchen, or listen to Adult Contemporary.All in all this is a fun game to play around with.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												I love Beat Hazard, and I'm not really a fan of twin stick shooters. I bought the game because it had an interesting premise, and I loved the game because it really succeeds in turning that premise into a great time. Beat Hazard has almost a Guitar Hero/Rock Band feel without the gimmicky side effect; it is a game that will have you playing for hours just because "oh, (song name) had a great beat for this! I want to try (song name)!" And this is as your spouse/friends/family is sitting beside you, watching you play while asking incessantly, "Can I try? Can I try?"The playability is literally endless. Literally. Music will always exist and new music will continue to be made, and you can play this game to the beat of said music via the form of mp3s (among others) and streaming. Be prepared to download songs you never wanted to admit liking just to try them out in the game. Be surprised as you find that certain songs offer you more challenge than you thought they would. When Beat Hazard claims the gameplay flows with the music, they're not just saying that. The beat picks up, the enemies fly faster, the colors get brighter, the bullets shoot faster. This offers a new level of strategy unheard of in other games, because if you know the song you are playing well, you'll know when it picks up and slows down and you can play accordingly. A few last positives before I end the review. The game tracks your high scores for each song that you have (for downloads, at least, I haven't tried with streaming). The game is easy to learn and great fun even for those (like me) who don't tend to like twin stick shooters. Great to launch at parties/get togethers/game nights. Great game to jump in/out of if you only have a few minutes to spare gaming. Multiple modes and unlockables. "Just one more" type of gameplay. Can be humorous at times to watch the enemy ships react to the music. It's actually kind of cute to watch them all quickly file onto the screen in a song that picks up quickly after a slow start, as if they all were sleeping off the screen until the blaring beat shook them to consciousness.Overall, great game. I'm giving it a 10/10. Buy it if you like music. ;)

Posted: January 1, 2014
												A very simple game; yet tons of fun that can last you for ages.It has a similar mechanic to Bullet Hell games. Bad guys shoot you, you avoid bullets and shoot back; easy!It has a ranking system, which mostly serves it's purpose for showing off especially when you get to the elite rank, from there it's just Elite 1, Elite 2 and so on.There are plenty of perks to go about. More lives, an extra percentage to all points gained from an enemy, more missiles and superbombs.It would be nice to have a campaign of sorts with it; but the other modes make up for that with Boss Rush and Survival both which can get very hectic quite fast.And above all; it plays by your music which is something I thoroughly enjoy. Be it fast paced, blaring rock/metal or something more relaxed and gentle, whatever song you pick, the game changes in what enemies will spawn, how fast they shoot, how powerful your shots are etc.Worth giving a go if you want to just waste a few hours...or weeks.

												If you like music ( of your own choosing) , fighting enemies, and like psychodellic images, well this is the game for you. Real fun and you can even choose the pace (depending on what song you select , will enable the pace of the enemies and your own weapons.) number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												“10/10 would seize again!” - The Joy of Stiqs“A revolutionary tool.. [has been] invaluable in continued research” - National Epilepsy Diagnostics Foundation“A true thriller that had me shaking in my boots.. and then in my chair.. followed shortly by the floor.” - PartialSandwichTasteless epileptic jokes aside, this game is fantastic. Beat Hazard is a twin-stick bullet-mayhem shooter very much akin to the Geometry Wars franchise. While the mechanics are quite similar, Beat Hazard makes the game your own by allowing your personal music collection to generate the levels you play.The game comes with about 20 or 30 tracks (all of which are pretty awesome) but nothing quite compares to the screen going mental when the beat drops in your favorite song. Speaking of the screen going mental, I tend to be bemused by games that put the photo-sensitivity warning before the game begins. I don’t understand the mechanics by which a seizure is induced but typically games have that warning when the only light flickering is a lamp swinging and sparking from the ceiling. Beat Hazard on the other hand means business, I have never seen such chaos in all my life!But here is the incredible part: the developers have masterfully balanced all the elements of the game so that even amidst all the chaos you know exactly what you’re doing. It was truly baffling to me when I played my very first game. I don’t know how they pulled it off but the design of this game is top notch. A must buy in my opinion!

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
Never Ending Music Game! [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]This game is unbelievable! At first I thought it was just another Geometry Wars clone (and in a certain way, it is), but due to the fact it is totally dependent on the music you let it play (yes, you use your own music!) it competes in a different league.The aim of the game is simple: enemy spacecrafts appear on the screen and you have to shoot all of them down; these will give you bonuses and powerups that will come in handy when facing the bigger and badder spacecrafts (the "end level bosses")!Gone are the days when you had to shoot while listening an annoying soundtrack, this time you have to shoot FOR listening your favorite song! Pop, Techno, Country, every genre translates in a different gameplay.Replay value is quite high: there are lot of achievements and at easier difficulties it is a good stress relief.I found the blinding acid graphic not distracting at all and simply amazing: another positive point for the game. It is the best game of this type on the market.The DLC is the icing on the cake, adding longevity and new enemies.Best played with X360 JoypadRecommended Buy Price < 15$Score 8/10

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												It's Asteroids, the Epilepsy Edition.Beat Hazard is a very fun arcade shooter where you pilot a ship, power it up, and destroy anything in your way, all to your own music. The control is great (allows for keyboard or controller) and the effects are pretty amazing, very bright and colorful. Also, there are many additional ships by designers in the Workshop, so experimenting around with other people's ships (and making your own) adds to the fun. The intensity of the enemy waves increases based on difficulty level and the intensity of your music. Obviously, some genres of music will be more preferable than others.If you're going to get this game, I highly recommend getting all the DLC. iTunes support will obviously let you play your iTunes files, Shadow Ops gives you objectives to complete in the game to raise your rank (allowing you to pick certain ships in the Workshop), and Ultra will add a wider variety of enemies (and probably other stuff, I don't know). Overall, Beat Hazard is a fun game that I keep coming back to periodically as a stress-reliever. Sometimes you just wanna blow sh*t up and listen to your favorite music, and this game does a great job of combining them both.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												First off if you have issues with strobe lights or any sort of light effected chance of seizures do not play this game. If you don't have any such problems, then play this game. Fast paced, up beat and very customizable it's a flashing ball of fun. I normally don't play shooters of this nature but this one has a nice learning curve for new comers, and more traditional crazy hard stuff for more experienced gamers. You can add your own music (which sets the structure of each level), use internet radio or just jam out with the music provided with the game. The amount of replay is almost endless because of this feature, with each new song creating a brand new level. As visiuals go, it's not exaclty the most advanced looking but man is it pretty. The constant flashing lights, ever changing colors and sparks remind me of a rave...or the 4th of July.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												I like videogames.  I like music.  I like having my retinas assaulted by swirls of colorful space dust.If you enjoy treating your brain to videogames and music like I do, and are enthralled with the amalgamation of the two, then there’s a good chance you’re going to enjoy Beat Hazard as well.  The twist is that Beat Hazard uses your own music to create custom levels.Beat Hazard uses songs from your computer, so you can choose which song you want to play and the game creates a level around it.  Levels begin like the arcade classic, Asteroids, where you reduce large hunks of space rocks into smaller pieces with your lasers before some mean old spaceships arrive to provide put up a fight.  The unique aspect of the game is that everything from  the velocity of the asteroids to the quanity of boss ships you fight is dependent upon the music.Blasting enemy ships into space rubble provides power-ups, which increase your firepower and the volume of the  music.  Your weapons are also influenced by the tune of the music, so when a song is softer or hits a quiet spot, your firepower is greatly reduced.  It’s like the gunner on the ship is a little kid sucking down fistfulls of Pixie Sticks.  He’s running around screaming with his hands in the air one minute and the instant the song tones it down a bit, he is lulled to sleep.In addition to determining the patterns of the enemies, the game’s visuals are also greatly affected by the song selection.   As the ship is upgraded, its firepower is transformed from simple white blips into a seizure-inducing kaleidoscope of doom.  Spots in the background that initially appear nondescript also pulsate and swirl with colors to the song’s beat.  It’s something straight out of a Hawkwind concert (or Pink Floyd, for those not in tune with their ’70s space rock).  The background effects intensify the point where it can seem like you’re trying to play a game through a late-90s Windows Media Player visualizer.Did you ever watch those visualizers and imagine playing a game through it?  Me neither.  That’s because while the visuals are quite impressive and make the game infinitely more compelling for onlookers, they are also a serious hindrance to actually playing the game.  I frequently find myself dying thanks to something that I either didn’t see or assumed was just a part of the background.  I suppose it could be argued that the visuals are a way of increasing the game’s difficulty, particularly for longer songs.Crazy psychedelic visuals and customizable soundtracks are about as useful as a chainsaw to a beaver if the game feels like a chore to play, and thankfully the meat of Beat Hazard is excellent.  I find twin-stick shooters to be stressful at times because of the never-ending onslaught of ever-increasing enemies, but Beat Hazard is refreshing because your targets appear in waves.  Depending on the song, you tend to have a few seconds to catch your breath before preparing for the next attack.One of the unintended benefits of the game is that it gives me an impetus to root through my music collection and dust off some tunes I have not heard in awhile.  I love shuffling through my songs and thinking “Hmm, I wonder what this song will be like?”  I find that in general, songs tend to work better if they are more dynamic and have a lot of changes in their volume or beats.The game does a great job of tracking your progress and keeping a tally of how many songs you have beaten, or if you have finished an entire album.  Even if you don’t complete a song, the game still awards experience and you can still gain levels which add bonuses and a feeling of persistence.  Achievements would be a fantastic addition to this game, but unfortunately are absent through no fault of Cold Beam Games.Despite it being a little too mesmerizing for its own good, Beat Hazard is an amazing experience and quite the technical accomplishment.  It is easy to recommend laying down the $5 for gamers who are music enthusiasts.  Outside of the allure of playing your own music,  Beat Hazard is an exciting and unique shooter and a great addition to the Indie library.Recommended

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I played this well into the night of Christmas Eve, into the early morning of Christmas itself many years ago. I was too anxious to sleep since Santa Claus was on his way, so I opted to venture into the living room in the dead of the night while everyone else was asleep. I had just recently bought and installed Beat Hazard and decided to have a go at it. In what seemed like five or so minutes, I was hooked like I was on drugs, this game is like a combination of LSD, Cannabis, the Magic Mushrooms and all that hippy stuff that makes you see the purple rhinoceros.Eventually, the computer crashed since it was a piece of junk, and I continued staring at the screen for several minutes. Just staring at the pitch black monitor. I finally came to and looked at the clock hanging on the wall. It was 5 o'clock. I had just experience what was perhaps the most intense, colourful and psychologically damaging ecstasy ride I might ever feel in my lifetime.When you play this game, you don't blink, you don't breathe, you don't do anything but watch, play and think of nothing. Your soul is absorbed into the monitor as it displays the flashing lights of hypnotism that is Beat Hazard and just when you think it couldn't get any trippier than that, you realise the light intensity goes past 100%.If I had to make any critical points against this game, it would be that there was no evil mastermind attempting to control the world through the amazingly vivid colours that this game shoves into your brain.*Caution: This game contains the side effects of fur growth on the eyeballs, misplaced eyebrows and occasional brain-freezes. Please consult a doctor if you do not experience any of these symptoms as you may be playing the wrong game.*

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												This game is equal parts Geometry Wars, Guitar Hero, and visualization software. Similar to Asteroids, the perspective is top-down, and you have free reign to move your ship in any direction (however, you are limited by the borders of the screen). The ideal way to play this game is with an Xbox 360 controller, as it is a twin-stick shooter (similar to Smash TV).The major selling point is that it is also a visualizer. So, your "stages" are actually music tracks. The game ships with several dance/house/edm tracks, however you can add to that listing with music saved onto your hard drive, and for $1.00, you can add iTunes and m&a support. Because it's a visualizer, everything pulsates with the beat of the music; shots, powerups, and your ships lights all thump with the beat. Because of this, certain genres resonate better with it than others (club/hip hop/dance/edm/dubstep/soul/funk/pop being the best, with metal/psychobilly/punk being the most spasmatic). Interestingly, the game will sync enemies and bosses with the music, so when a song gets to a really intense part, you may suddenly get hit with twin bosses and similarly when there's not much going on in the track, you may wind up staring at an empty screen. The game also takes more detail into the game from your music selection by making adjustments to things like enemy/bullet speed, how many of your guns fire during the quieter segments, and how fast time-based score multiplier meters fill up.The ideal purchase to make for this game is the Mega Bundle Pack, as it contains all of the DLC (including the aforementioned iTunes/m&a licensing). These include online co-op/competitive play, new bosses, and perks that can be applied to your gameplay, and the Shadow Ops Unit DLC, which adds a rank progression system, ship-specific goals (like destroy 100 asteroids, reach 1,000,000 points in a track), leaderboards for each ship, and even opens up the ship creating system to you. The higher you rank in the Shadow Ops Unit, the more points you get in creating a ship. It also lets you select an image on your hard drive for the ship and upload your creation to the steam workshop for others to download and use. This also means that you can download ships that other users have created (I've seen quite a few Millennium Falcons, Starship Enterprises, X-Wing Fighters, and Tie Fighters, but have also seen the Planet Express Ship, ships from other shooters, and even the Tardis).However, due to the nature of this game's fast moving, brightly colored flashing particle effects, this is not something for epileptics to play or be around, as it will made them seize faster than Axl Rose would find a reason to not play a show. For the rest of us, the $16.99 price point for the Mega Bundle pack is really cheap. While there's virtually no story, it is quite fun to see what the game makes of your favorite music as well as push for the oldschool arcade goals of getting a high score.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												A fun game with a fair price and a great way to pass the time. IF you ever need an excuse to listen to mp3's for hours on end this will give you one.A small tip though; even though it seems counterintuitive- slow music increases the difficulty greatly! The softer music keeps your ship from firing at full power while heavy music is a blast-a-thon.Recommended Music:Nightwish. KMFDM. Industrial and EDM in general. For increased difficulty go with Radiohead, Flaming Lips, Classical, etc. Avoid Country music as it causes your pilot to get depressed and eject from the ship.

												Pros:1) You can play multiplayer versus or co-op but only if both players got same songs on their pc, with same tags and music length.2) Its genuinely hard.3) There's a lot of game modes and upgrades for your ship.4) There's an in-game radio.Cons:1) Searching for songs on your pc takes ages.2) Out of tens of thousands songs on my pc i usually had only a hundred (most of the times less) or so matches with other players.3) Its just too bright and colourful in my opinion. 												The game goes like this: you go PEWPEWPEW, bad guise go BOOMBOOM and your eyes bleed on higher difficulties.And now for realsies: It's a twin stick shooter, in which your ship is as powerful as your music. There's a selection of perks to suit everyone, unlockables, global scoreboards and pretty smooth co-op/versus mode. My eyes burn and I'm loving it!

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Unoffical subtitle "The Epileptic's Nightmare".Beat Hazard is a game that lies along the same vein as Audiosurf, only instead of a racing game its a space shooter (think Asteroids, that really old game with the triangle ship).  You can use the music you have on your computer to power the battlefield as you blast away your foes.  It's a simple, but addicting game, especially with the DLC that adds the Shadow Missions (objectives for you to complete with different ships).  The gameplay is simple: you shoot the living crap out of anything that moves on-screen while trying not to get exploded.The only major issue I have with this game is that the visuals are sometimes too distracting.  I usually turn the visual intensity option down to 50% when I play, because otherwise it actually kinda hurts my eyes.  This also makes it hard to see some of the projectiles coming towards you, resulting in some really cheap deaths where you literally couldn't see what blew you up.  Since you basically die in one hit, it can be a pain, especially if you're trying to complete a Shadow Mission.Other than that it's a load of fun to hop in and blow up enemies while listening to your favorite music.  It's well worth the bundle that includes all the DLC as well if it goes on sale.  Buying it full price really depends on how much fun you think you'll have with it.  It's definitely more hardcore than the likes of Audiosurf.  If that's your thing, then put your money down and get shooting.

content:
Posted: March 25
One of the awesome & great games that I enjoy on Steam ever!This game is very awesome to play with our favorite music ever, especially it's similar to Geometry Wars since we:  Move around in the zone. Shoot down the enemies and deadly asteroids. Dodge those enemies' damn attacks and hulls. Kick those awesome giant ship bosses' engines. Lose all lives and fail the current stages/music.Since this game is a music powered game, it's also suitable for the fans of the video game music remixes and the music from the Newgrounds Audio Portal including that epic hardcore song "Through the Fire and Flames".The two ships "Star Runner" and "Dragon Fire" are very good for the suicidal difficulty and I still consider it as very good skill. But it isn't even part of faking expert skills.Not to mention that this game is actually rated E (for everyone) by ESRB.Here also comes my facts involving myself for this game in this reviewI had chosen this game as my primary favorite game of the music-based procedural generation game collection because I wanted to enjoy shooting down the enemies & bosses, dodging their attacks & hulls and especially avoid losing lives & failing the music.What I actually enjoy in this game...is by absolutely playing my favorite video game music remixes, metal covers and medleys by Jonny Atma, DJ the S and the OverClocked ReMix community. Not just those kinds but also my favorite music from the Newgrounds Audio Portal since I've also known many of my favorite music from there since my childhood and even my favorite I Wanna Be The Guy fangames. Nintendo game, Touhou and Castlevania music for the win too!It's also pretty funny that...I identify gender for the ships as I refer the star runner ship as a female and the dragon fire ship as a male but even every bosses as males too. But enemies are genderless or maybe males also, I decide.I also do YouTube videos of my completion runs of every songs I play in this game like replays and memories both together but on my alternate channel about getting high scores on the songs in the music powered games like this game "Beat Hazard".Anyway, I am hoping that I can complete all of my favorite video game music remixes/metal covers/medleys in this game ever. It will be an epic piece of the sweetest cake and even a mastery diamond medal for doing all of those on the suicidal difficulty. I'll nail it. (Get the hint about a mastery diamond medal? Yep, mastery mode from Bloons TD 5 on platforms rather than web and diamond medal from Bloons Super Monkey 2 on mobile)You and I should actually start off with the GaMetal music of "Beware the Forest's Mushrooms" (from Super Mario RPG) and the Touhou Remix Project music "Miko Xanadu" (by DJ the S) if we are really fans of Nintendo and Touhou though. Cool, huh?

												*NOTE* This review specifically covers Beat Hazard Ultra


YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Beat Hazard Ultra 

			Views: 2,972		

			Senior Reviewer Trent takes a look at Beat Hazard to see if this twin stick shooter just an uninspired gimmick, or a great new way to experience your music collection.		

+Using your music as the soundtrack is not just a gimmick+Perks and upgrades give you a reason to keep playing+Classic pick up and play arcade style gameplay-Visuals will give some fatal seizures (do NOT play if you have epilepsy)-With perks it can become easy-Your music taste will affect your enjoyment of the game.If Geometry Wars and Winamp had a baby they would name it Beat Hazard.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												After 10+ hours I can say one can't GET epilepsy. So I will still play the game :DStill this can't be good for eyes.-----------------------------------------------Edit to add something as someone didn't like my suggestion (1/2) so turning it into a review:The game is pretty fast paced. And slow songs won't make the game easier. You can play with any song and the game includes radio stations. The key of surviving a song is how  long it is as you don't get extra lives during it, but extra bombs every X minutes. On regular songs once on the middle.You can adjust the difficulty level and you can unlock harder difficulties.You can adjust the visual impact 50, 75, 100, 125, 150, 175 and 200% depending on how mad you want to become after your session.There are powerups to increase damage and volume of the music and point multipliers. You can unlock to get more bombs, increase the multipliers for not shooting and surviving and get powerups from the start of the level.Some achievements are easy some are hard and other seem impossibru. Maybe on easier modes, but then you will get bored of the level to get them. I played on difficult all the game but had to move to suicide -there's a harder mode- to be able to get more than 1 million points on a short song (1 m points on all default songs achievement). Will have to reduce difficulty to be able to survive a long enough song to defeat 8 bosses, they appear not regularly, you may not find any on 3-4 minutes and suddenly be fighting two at the same time.I always liked those ships shooters and I enjoyed this one a lot. I can't do other thing than recommend you all and invite you to survive to your favourite songs on this excellent game.I'm going to try to get the dlc on a cheap price during sales to get the new ships with different weaponry.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Beat Hazard is a top-down procedurally generated shooter which takes your music files and generates waves of enemies that synchronize to the music. The purpose is to get a high score, while using various power ups (volume, multipliers, points, etc) to facilitate this score. As you play, there are a series of upgrades which can modify your game to allow for different challenges and playstyles.Ultimately, it's a fun top-down bullet hell shooter which has a good bit of variety. Worth a look if those sorts of games interest you.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												A twin-stick shooter, mixed with an Audiosurf-style music engine, mixed with a dance party. Beat Hazard is a flashy, spectacular, intense game that looks glorious on your big-screen TV... unless you're epileptic. Its built-in soundtrack is a groovy electronica mix of various indie artists and styles, but in Beat Hazard you can never complain about the crap music, since it hooks in to your own music library.As a twin-stick shooter it's more style than substance. The controls are decent, your weapons range from tiny lasers to huge lasers (depending on the intensity of your music at any given time), and there's a range of enemies. But it's not the game you play when you want a twin-stick shooter.It's great when you set it on "Easy", put on some music you like, get a drink, treat it as a WinAmp visualiser, and chillax the heck out.Get the "Ultra" version, which makes the shooter part of the game a bit more varied.Recommendation: buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Beat Hazard was one of the first indie games that really stuck out and stayed with me, even after five years. It has a staying power that the likes of Audiosurf doesn't have, because unlike the aforementioned, Beat Hazard has an overwhelming sense of style with the blinding, epilepsy-inducing light show it puts out and the fast-paced carnage that plays like ADHD bullet hell on the higher difficulties, except the enemy ships are the bullets. Audiosurf is more of a pretty looking acid trip with confusing and distracting color-matching mechanics, while Beat Hazard stays true to its concept of an arcade space shooter that turns everything up to eleven and adds some bass boost in the mix. Once the hours you spend into the game pay off and you start to master the highest difficulty, all the chaos comes into place in full clarity, and you suddenly play the role of conductor in a controlled cacophony with a stupidly big grin on your face.The result is as approachable yet always thrilling as it is visually arresting and immensely replayable. A combination of classic Asteroids mechanics and procedural generation by music, included in the package are tons of unlockables and power-ups, online play and co-op, modes like survival and boss rush, great additional content, and Steam Workshop.Simply put, it's one of my favorite indie games of all time, and the best twin-stick space shooter there ever will be, in my opinion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												If you love music, space action, and the thrill of the risk of having a seizure, then you will love this game! The difficulty of the higher settings may be a turn-off to some, but If you play at a comfortable level it's a blast to play. While it is essentially a very flashy and syncronized game of Asteroids, it is something to behold if you enjoy both games and music.One thing you want before this game is fast, energetic music. Slower songs tend to be a bit of a drag to play, and really slow everything down to a screeching halt. If all you listen to is acoustic guitar ballads and the occasional ambient music, this game may not be for you. This game works best with faster music, obviously, so if you have some dubstep, punk, high-energy electronic or metal on there you will have a blast.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2010
												This game takes me back to the days of Raystorm and other old-school arcade shooters. *can finally put those gamepad analog sticks to good use!*has non-boring achievements (if you're an "achiever" type gamer at all) *progression...in an arcade game, yeah, you heard right. :DI mean, who's ever heard of leveling up in game like this?! Add to that: you can listen to your own music. I think it's more for casual play, but for a lot of people, that's ideal. The achievements do make it more addictive.EDIT: WITH ULTRA the game got that much better, obviously, adding more enemy variety and more modes.WITH Shadow Ops: more ship types for you to choose from; more progression, more ships to unlock, and unlimited fun with steam workshop (never-ending supply of user-created ships)TR;DR= If you like your music at all and casual games at all,THEN GET THIS GAME. Also, it's really the best music-based game out there, right up there with Audiosurf (although on sheer fun factor, I have to give the edge to Beat Hazard).

												This is a very straightforward game.  Asteroids/Sinistar 2D view.  One stick flies ship around.  The other aims/fires gunes (at least on a controller). It is the Stem version of Redbull.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2011
												Developed by Cold Beam Games in an underground bunker where a separate team was trying to resurrect Jesus Christ. This may or may not be relevant.A game so utter in its simplicity, yet so GLORIOUS in its execution, Beat Hazard has resulted in thousands of murder-suicides across the globe, the perpetrators generally reasoning that the rest of the world is now "just one big letdown". The game is a source of untold joy, having brought the wonders of synesthesia and/or ocular hemorrhage to you kids at home. It has shown entire generations the true meaning of life, and, in one case, actually caused a blind man to see again, albeit in an enitrely new spectrum not known to mankind.In summation, the game is the beautiful love-child of Asteroids, Geometry Wars, Audiosurf, and an epileptic seizure in a neon paint store. Spend the ten bucks, you cheap dou­che, and your eyeballs and your ears will love you forever.Or you might go blind. It's hard to tell.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												UPDATED - New SHADOW OPERATIONS dlc has been released and thus has changed the scoring for this game.Game: Beat Hazard UltraGenre: Music ShooterDeveloper: Cold Beam GamesSystem: Steam (PC)Total Score: 88/100Value Score: 8.8/10• Story: */10o The game has no storyline whatsoever.• Characters: 8/10o There are no actual characters in the game but the objects within the game feature themselves as a type of character. You have several types of enemies with all sorts of appearances and attacks that come in many forms and shapes. There are about 3-4 different type of bosses each with unique form and attack. There are also mini boss versions of the bosses. There's also the player character or player characters if you go multiplayer. UPDATE - There are more ships now to play as than before and now the option to play as community created ships makes the selection quite appealing.• GamePlay: 10/10o The game is like a Japanese side scroller shooter which you play as a vehicle and destroy objects that come towards you in the form of meteors, debris, enemy ships, or just giant creatures. You must destroy them to get points and power ups which can do a multitude of things such as a multipler which can increase your score, a P power up which increases your attack power, a VOL power up which increases the volume of the music (in which affects your basic shooting attack pattern and burst shot). You can pretty much use the built in music collection or import your own tracks to play in the background of the game. The music affects your shot attacks, affects the enemy presence and how some power ups are distributed or appear - it is all based on Rhythm or the beat of the game. You have the choice to play single player, multiplayer, boss mode (which you fight bosses non-stop), or even the ability to play the classic Beat Hazard game upon start up for a different visual appearance and different UI. There are ranks which you can achieve based on raking up points from each game you do along with the fact you can unlock/use bonuses in the form of perks you can equip to make things interesting such as increased difficulty or giving you a boost of power in the beginning of a game.• Graphics: 7/10o Although the game isnt as graphic intense as most other recent games the game shines at its own creativity. The music itself develops the intensity of the lighting and special effects - depending on the rhythm different colors and splashes may occur which adds variety to the game and gives you a adrenaline rush feeling. However its best to stay back otherwise you'll have a high chance of getting a Seizure (as the game warns you as well when you start it).• Sound: 7/10o The game has basic sound effects for explosions, attacks and going through the menu. It feels and sounds like you are literally in a early 1990s or a late 1980s game which is quite nostalgic. There are no voice overs or anything unless you count what you hear in the music or the built in radio.• Music: 10/10o The game features a set of tracks already built in along with some radio stations for players who have no music on their computer. The reason why this aspect receives a perfect score is the ability to add your own music to the game which is the ultimate option for this aspect.• Length: 6/10o Because the game consists of a side scroller shooter with limited music (and you can add more music) with no direction or storyline the game's length is quite minimal. There are ranks and bonuses in the form of perks you can unlock however should only take you no more than 3 hours to get everything unlocked. UPDATE - Due to the inclusion of the Shadow Operations DLC - there's more to unlock in terms of content (ships) and ranks.• Replay Value: 10/10o Although the game has no direction, it allows you to pave your own direction with the ability to put your own music you can play this game and get a different result each time you play. Every game is absolutely different. If single player isnt enough to satisfy your hunger you can do multiplayer co-op or even competitive. There's also boss mode and of course you add music tracks of your own to change up the pace of the game. You can also unlock additional difficulties through perks.• Player Value: 10/10o This game is absolutely recommended especially for fans of the music genre, love music and loves shooters. The game is also a great multiplayer experience as you can play all the modes in competitive or co-op (this includes the boss rush mode). You can import your own music or use the built in music or radio stations to give you a different experience each time you play. This is a great game for both hardcore fanatics who want to brag about points or compete with each other and super casuals who just want something to spend time on even if it is for just one game.

												Its alright for a few minutes at a time.  Gameplay is interesting in concept, and the music idea is fun. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Beat Hazard was one of the first indie games that really stuck out and stayed with me, even after five years. It has a staying power that the likes of Audiosurf doesn't have, because unlike the aforementioned, Beat Hazard has an overwhelming sense of style with the blinding, epilepsy-inducing light show it puts out and the fast-paced carnage that plays like ADHD bullet hell on the higher difficulties, except the enemy ships are the bullets. Audiosurf is more of a pretty looking acid trip with confusing and distracting color-matching mechanics, while Beat Hazard stays true to its concept of an arcade space shooter that turns everything up to eleven and adds some bass boost in the mix. Once the hours you spend into the game pay off and you start to master the highest difficulty, all the chaos comes into place in full clarity, and you suddenly play the role of conductor in a controlled cacophony with a stupidly big grin on your face.The result is as approachable yet always thrilling as it is visually arresting and immensely replayable. A combination of classic Asteroids mechanics and procedural generation by music, included in the package are tons of unlockables and power-ups, online play and co-op, modes like survival and boss rush, great additional content, and Steam Workshop.Simply put, it's one of my favorite indie games of all time, and the best twin-stick space shooter there ever will be, in my opinion.

												Beat Hazard is a lot of fun to play in short bursts, but gets samey after a while (unless you're the sort of person for whom beating a worldwide high score is as gratifying as seeing your child's smile). If you often find yourself in situations where you need to kill 15-30 minutes, Beat Hazard will do the trick nicely. The Ultra DLC is worthwhile and changes the gameplay in significant ways, Shadow Operations DLC is basically extra grind.Keep in mind that the game does not support Unicode, so if your music files are tagged with non-Latin characters, you will be staring at rows of question marks instead of artist and track names.

												Just a heads up: Do NOT buy this game if you suffer epilepsy or something like that. There are a TON of flashing lights in this game.I remember a year or so ago that I first heard of it in a video I can't remember what it was about. I decided to get it since I was kinda curious and I liked the idea of gameplay based on music, as I enjoyed audiosurf myself. It kinda just sat there for a while. And with a while I mean over a year. So now I tried it again and played some vidya tunes on it. And I must say, it's quite enjoyable.To put it simply, this is a 2D, dare I say arcade-like shooter. But the 'levels' to put it like there are based of the soundtrack you choose, and the more intense the music is, the more things happen on the screen. There's probably also something with the rhythm, but I didn't notice it all that much. But I'm probably missing something. There are different enemies and bosses. Most of them vary from size, projectiles, and movement paths, to put it like that. That's really all I can say for the enemies. Oh right there are bosses as well I suppose.There are also perks you can unlock by playing (or that is part of the ultra DLC pack. Which I think it is.), Which are basically bonuses to help you out, or unlock some new stuff.In the end. I can recommend this game if you have some money in your steam wallet which you don't know what to spend it on, if it's on sale, or you are just curious. I myself think this is a pretty good game to play if you're bored and want to shoot things while listening to any song from Metal Gear Rising or any Pursuit theme from Ace Attorney. That's simply the best thing.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Beat Hazard is a top-down procedurally generated shooter which takes your music files and generates waves of enemies that synchronize to the music. The purpose is to get a high score, while using various power ups (volume, multipliers, points, etc) to facilitate this score. As you play, there are a series of upgrades which can modify your game to allow for different challenges and playstyles.Ultimately, it's a fun top-down bullet hell shooter which has a good bit of variety. Worth a look if those sorts of games interest you.
