												Beat Hazard is a game that is difficult review because everyone is going to have a different experience. So  I'm simply going  to share my experience with Beat hazard. Beat hazard is my dream come true. Before Beat Hazard I would Cry in the corner of my room wishing there was a game where I could fly around space blowing everything up while blasting weeaboo and simultaniously melting my corneas.  Then one day while browsing through the humble bundle, there was Beat Hazard. I instantly emptied all of my money into this bundle just for Beat Hazard and the next thing I knew I was taken on a journey through space blasting space junk to Van Halen's Runnin with the devil. All while breaking analog sticks on my controller and bleeding through my eyes. Would definitely recomend for the full price.10/10 would shoot spaceships to a recording of Morgan Freemans voice again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												UPDATED - New SHADOW OPERATIONS dlc has been released and thus has changed the scoring for this game.Game: Beat Hazard UltraGenre: Music ShooterDeveloper: Cold Beam GamesSystem: Steam (PC)Total Score: 88/100Value Score: 8.8/10• Story: */10o The game has no storyline whatsoever.• Characters: 8/10o There are no actual characters in the game but the objects within the game feature themselves as a type of character. You have several types of enemies with all sorts of appearances and attacks that come in many forms and shapes. There are about 3-4 different type of bosses each with unique form and attack. There are also mini boss versions of the bosses. There's also the player character or player characters if you go multiplayer. UPDATE - There are more ships now to play as than before and now the option to play as community created ships makes the selection quite appealing.• GamePlay: 10/10o The game is like a Japanese side scroller shooter which you play as a vehicle and destroy objects that come towards you in the form of meteors, debris, enemy ships, or just giant creatures. You must destroy them to get points and power ups which can do a multitude of things such as a multipler which can increase your score, a P power up which increases your attack power, a VOL power up which increases the volume of the music (in which affects your basic shooting attack pattern and burst shot). You can pretty much use the built in music collection or import your own tracks to play in the background of the game. The music affects your shot attacks, affects the enemy presence and how some power ups are distributed or appear - it is all based on Rhythm or the beat of the game. You have the choice to play single player, multiplayer, boss mode (which you fight bosses non-stop), or even the ability to play the classic Beat Hazard game upon start up for a different visual appearance and different UI. There are ranks which you can achieve based on raking up points from each game you do along with the fact you can unlock/use bonuses in the form of perks you can equip to make things interesting such as increased difficulty or giving you a boost of power in the beginning of a game.• Graphics: 7/10o Although the game isnt as graphic intense as most other recent games the game shines at its own creativity. The music itself develops the intensity of the lighting and special effects - depending on the rhythm different colors and splashes may occur which adds variety to the game and gives you a adrenaline rush feeling. However its best to stay back otherwise you'll have a high chance of getting a Seizure (as the game warns you as well when you start it).• Sound: 7/10o The game has basic sound effects for explosions, attacks and going through the menu. It feels and sounds like you are literally in a early 1990s or a late 1980s game which is quite nostalgic. There are no voice overs or anything unless you count what you hear in the music or the built in radio.• Music: 10/10o The game features a set of tracks already built in along with some radio stations for players who have no music on their computer. The reason why this aspect receives a perfect score is the ability to add your own music to the game which is the ultimate option for this aspect.• Length: 6/10o Because the game consists of a side scroller shooter with limited music (and you can add more music) with no direction or storyline the game's length is quite minimal. There are ranks and bonuses in the form of perks you can unlock however should only take you no more than 3 hours to get everything unlocked. UPDATE - Due to the inclusion of the Shadow Operations DLC - there's more to unlock in terms of content (ships) and ranks.• Replay Value: 10/10o Although the game has no direction, it allows you to pave your own direction with the ability to put your own music you can play this game and get a different result each time you play. Every game is absolutely different. If single player isnt enough to satisfy your hunger you can do multiplayer co-op or even competitive. There's also boss mode and of course you add music tracks of your own to change up the pace of the game. You can also unlock additional difficulties through perks.• Player Value: 10/10o This game is absolutely recommended especially for fans of the music genre, love music and loves shooters. The game is also a great multiplayer experience as you can play all the modes in competitive or co-op (this includes the boss rush mode). You can import your own music or use the built in music or radio stations to give you a different experience each time you play. This is a great game for both hardcore fanatics who want to brag about points or compete with each other and super casuals who just want something to spend time on even if it is for just one game.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Pros:Incredibly hard difficulties are opportune for those who are well practiced in surpassing impossible odds.Fast music means fast gameplay, and stong elements of bass, wild riffs, and resonsant harmonies ALL add to the overall power of your guns. I highly recommend going to bandcamp and getting The Helix Nebula - Meridian.LOTS of arcade style replay value. If you're into arcade gaming, and this style of game that is.Lots of records to beat, and things to unlock. I love unlocking things in arcade games.------Cons:DLC is too pricey at full price for what you get. Recommend spending no more then 2-4 for Ultra, and 2-3 for Shadow Ops.They make you pay for access to workshop elements. I mean seriously... I don't really use workshop on anything, but... WTF?Bosses and waves occur at same times every song, every game. Not much variation, and would be cool if it synched bosses with the strongest points of the songs. Some songs have lulls aligned with boss fights, and that's a death sentence.Full price for game is much like the full price for DLC. A bit too high.------Would I recommend this?...If you like arcade games, or hate not being able to listen to your own music with your games often, YES.If you get tired of repetitive challenges, Don't like to challenege yourself with insane difficulty settings, or focus too much on the negatives of things rather enjoying what you've got, No. This game has simplicity, and should be enjoyed with simplicity.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												At the time I was clueless as to why I was sitting in the holding cell. I had finished another terse interrogation consisting of a lot of shouting on the part of my interviewer and my characteristic recalcitrant silence. I was thrown back into my cell and made to await more verbal abuse from the world's greatest state sanctioned gang. Suddenly, there was a great cacophony that sounded like trumpets and dying men. The walls around me crumbled and my interrogator had lost his eyes and was bleeding from them. An angel bore a standard on his wings and it was the sign of the cross. Finally, Jesus Christ had acknowledged I was the true savior of the universe and my time here was done.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I'm sure i cant say anything that hasn't already been said about this game. Its a very common type of shooter with its own unique (and rather wonderful) twist: it plays to your music. Every album you own becomes a fight for survival as you dodge lasers, asteroids and giant boss ships, and fight back with guitar riffs and heavy bass. Did i mention its also very beautiful to look at? The amazing use of color makes it feel like a graphic equalizer as your lasers pulse to the beat. play to your favorite songs, or play against your friends and try to beat their high score for their favorite. (when writing this) I haven't even played for an hour yet and i can tell this is a game i will be coming back to often.Pros- Varying difficulty for different skill groups- neverending replayablilty - each track is a new challenge- visually good to look at- with the Shadow Operatives DLC you can fly whatever ship you want. care to pilot an X-wing while listening to the Duel of Fates? Or maybe you'd rather fly a hippie van while chilling out with Jimmie Hendrix. If you have even a little skill with photoshop or even free software like gimp you can turn a png of your vessle into a usable spacecraft.cons - i dont want to imply this game is Perfect for everybody, but i cannot find any real flaws in this game... except maybe for those people who try playing to Taylor Swift...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2011
												Beat Hazard is a lot of fun to play in short bursts, but gets samey after a while (unless you're the sort of person for whom beating a worldwide high score is as gratifying as seeing your child's smile). If you often find yourself in situations where you need to kill 15-30 minutes, Beat Hazard will do the trick nicely. The Ultra DLC is worthwhile and changes the gameplay in significant ways, Shadow Operations DLC is basically extra grind.Keep in mind that the game does not support Unicode, so if your music files are tagged with non-Latin characters, you will be staring at rows of question marks instead of artist and track names.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Pros:Incredibly hard difficulties are opportune for those who are well practiced in surpassing impossible odds.Fast music means fast gameplay, and stong elements of bass, wild riffs, and resonsant harmonies ALL add to the overall power of your guns. I highly recommend going to bandcamp and getting The Helix Nebula - Meridian.LOTS of arcade style replay value. If you're into arcade gaming, and this style of game that is.Lots of records to beat, and things to unlock. I love unlocking things in arcade games.------Cons:DLC is too pricey at full price for what you get. Recommend spending no more then 2-4 for Ultra, and 2-3 for Shadow Ops.They make you pay for access to workshop elements. I mean seriously... I don't really use workshop on anything, but... WTF?Bosses and waves occur at same times every song, every game. Not much variation, and would be cool if it synched bosses with the strongest points of the songs. Some songs have lulls aligned with boss fights, and that's a death sentence.Full price for game is much like the full price for DLC. A bit too high.------Would I recommend this?...If you like arcade games, or hate not being able to listen to your own music with your games often, YES.If you get tired of repetitive challenges, Don't like to challenege yourself with insane difficulty settings, or focus too much on the negatives of things rather enjoying what you've got, No. This game has simplicity, and should be enjoyed with simplicity.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
Originally posted by CynicalPopcorn:OH FOR F*** SAKE I DIED RIGHT AT THE END OF THE SONG F***... F*** this game. I love it.CynicalPopcorn's HIGHLY Recommended! | 9.75/10Good value for money? YES!WARNING:The game has a LOT of bright, flashing lights and as such people with photosensitivity issues should take this into consideration.Beat Hazard SummaryA twin stick shooter not only powered by music, but powered by YOUR music! Beat Hazard takes your songs and puts you into a world of intense, twin-stick shooter action. The music you play really impacts the flow of the game from the enemies that spawn to how fast and frantic movement on the screen is, especially when taking into account the wonderful, very bright visuals.The game alone, "regular" Beat Hazard is awesome, however for the TRUE feel of the game purchasing the entire set of DLC is worth every penny. The "Ultra" DLC adds more ranks, new enemy, higher difficulty and improves the game all round. Then, to add to this chaos, the "Shadow Operations Unit" DLC adds a VERY nice element of challenge that adds a new ranking system along side the normal one which rewards the player for completing challenges. This, however, is not easy as a death during a challenge will set you back. Be it that the current song does not count towards a total of songs completed on 'x' difficulty, or that you lose ALL (yes, all) progress in that challenge, deaths are even more unbearable than usual.Please note: In order to use songs from iTunes you will need to purchase the "iTunes & m4a file support" DLC. It's cheap, and I understand why they've done it. You're best off buying the mega bundle anyway as all the DLC is worth it.ProsExcellent top-down, twin-stick shooter powered by your music library!Good difficulty curve that gets VERY tough at high difficulties.Incredibly fun to play!Great replayability - Many different enemies, bosses, gamemodes and each song is unique.Co-op or Competetive multiplayer fun.Gamemodes are very interesting and well done!Custom made ships that are actually quite balanced!ConsFlashing lights. Very bright flashing lights to be precise. A BIG WARNING to those who suffer from photosensitivity issues.JudgementBeat Hazard gets CynicalPopcorn's HIGHLY recommended judgement with a score of 9.75/10.The game is extremely fun with very high replayability. Difficulty is fair and the visuals are lovely. All-round well made twin-stick shooter that should not be overlooked by those who enjoy similar games like Audiosurf (music aspect) and want to try it with a bullet-hell twist.Also, yes that is a genuine quote. This game and I have an unstable relationship of me mostly yelling cause I play poorly followed by myself immediately crawling right back to it.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												A twin stick shooter that was made by a man who loves addictive gameplay as much as he hates epileptics. It's like Audiosurf's more aggressive and rave-y cousin. Very fun and overlooked, with its only real flaws being that it works best with very fast-paced music and that visual intensity affects score. Comes with a nice default library of songs that are fun to play and surprisingly good listening.  It also has a very interesting perk system that forces you to decide between the safety net of extra weapons/power-ups and boosting your multipliers to get the highest score possible.

content:

												At the time I was clueless as to why I was sitting in the holding cell. I had finished another terse interrogation consisting of a lot of shouting on the part of my interviewer and my characteristic recalcitrant silence. I was thrown back into my cell and made to await more verbal abuse from the world's greatest state sanctioned gang. Suddenly, there was a great cacophony that sounded like trumpets and dying men. The walls around me crumbled and my interrogator had lost his eyes and was bleeding from them. An angel bore a standard on his wings and it was the sign of the cross. Finally, Jesus Christ had acknowledged I was the true savior of the universe and my time here was done.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2013
												Either I'm high, the end of the world is near or this is all a dream and I've taken the role of Bruce Willis because any of these situations would make more sense than a game like this one actually being enjoyable. Beat Hazard is your standard Bullet Hell game where you are once again playing as a genocidal spaceship shooting down anything that doesn't get swallowed up and added to a multiplier. However the special twist it's got to keep it from being run of the mill is that it prides itself on being "powered by your music" . Now I know you've heard it a million times before and every single time it was just "your music plays in the background when the function decides to actually cooperate" cleverly disguised but Beat Hazard actually stays strong to the claim. There really is a very noticeable difference between playing classical music and playing fasted tempo trance. Beat Hazard is truly a fun Bullet Hell game and I am going to have to wash my mouth out for reading that aloud so this better at least convince someone to try it.

												If you love music and video game shooters, this is the game for you!I never play anything like this genre because I'm not into such, but boy do I love this one, not only the shooting can be really fun, but you can also play your favorite music!It's quite a beautiful game to look at, all the colors and the effects are amazing, just be careful with the intensity of the lights, I choose 50% (min), but you can go up to 200%, but I don't recommend it because it ain't good for your eyes and on top of that it's harder to play.Which brings me to difficulties.Playing on easiest it's just for chilling really, but you can go as high as Suicidal! 												Developed by Cold Beam Games in an underground bunker where a separate team was trying to resurrect Jesus Christ. This may or may not be relevant.A game so utter in its simplicity, yet so GLORIOUS in its execution, Beat Hazard has resulted in thousands of murder-suicides across the globe, the perpetrators generally reasoning that the rest of the world is now "just one big letdown". The game is a source of untold joy, having brought the wonders of synesthesia and/or ocular hemorrhage to you kids at home. It has shown entire generations the true meaning of life, and, in one case, actually caused a blind man to see again, albeit in an enitrely new spectrum not known to mankind.In summation, the game is the beautiful love-child of Asteroids, Geometry Wars, Audiosurf, and an epileptic seizure in a neon paint store. Spend the ten bucks, you cheap dou­che, and your eyeballs and your ears will love you forever.Or you might go blind. It's hard to tell.

												A great fun way to experience your music that will melt your eyes! Pros: Solid code that works well with lots of different kinds of musicGreat artworkAdjustable features such as brightness from 50-200%Use your own musicFun to play and challengingCons:No mouse control on menuNavigating to music folders is tedious if you have a large HD like I doWorkshop only available as a DLCThe only real con I have a major problem with is the last one. That aside, the game is fun and coded expertly and at times just amazing to watch.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												If you're searching for a rhythm game which at least somehow relates to the music you play to (in comparison to some other games *cough*), Beat Hazard is in my opinion the way to go. Along with the currently available DLC's, it adds up to a versatile casual game you can enjoy your music to (Or smack kitties with your keyboard if you try to get all of the achievements/perks/unlocks/whatever).GAMEPLAY:The gameplay is rather simple. It's Asteroids with the pace of the game adjusting to the pace of the music you chose. This could be local music or online radio streams (Great Addition, but restricted to the Ultra DLC). There is a little annoying bug which sometimes made my game not play any music anymore when i was playing to radio stations though. Give the game a restart and it was gone. Still annoying.The game also encourages you to play on until you got'em all. Perks, Upgrades (Beat Hazard Ultra DLC) and Ships (Shadow Operations DLC). If you're a completionist, that is. There is no specific reason to get all the unlocks after all.I'd give it a 8,5/10 because of the annoying radio bug (maybe only appearing to me) and the replay value (40 hours for few bucks is quite okay i guess).HOWEVER if you want to enjoy the game to the full potential i would really recommend getting the DLCs as well. It adds up to the game experience greatly as for new, different ships, online radio support, more enemies, more bosses, more modes and so on.

												I love music, and I love video games... and Beat Hazard allows me to enjoy these two passions at the same time!With the achievements in the game, I found myself coming back again and again to try and complete the Shadow Missions for each of the ships. I like the variety of gameplay the many different ships add to the game--and there are a nice selection in the base game. The price is just right in my opinion, and I'm sure future updates will make the game ever better!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												June 4, 2015A solid shooter, not exactly dependent on music. Music intensity affects the spawn of enemies and your firing rate, slowing to a crawl in silent parts. It's nice to play with your music, but this isn't Audiosurf-style interaction. I know the meme is to play with high visual intensity and abuse yourself, but just turn the visuals down to 50%. I wish there was a lower setting than that, as the visuals just cloud everything. No one cares what setting you use.New weapons make tracks more interesting, but the progression system makes the game hardest at the start. I wish there was a difficulty option between Hardcore and Insane, as there is a fair amount of time where you don't have the ship upgrades to reasonably beat long Insane songs, but Hardcore becomes too simple. The Shadow DLC is compelling, adding new ship options and support for auto-fire ships to further increase the variety. However, the DLC does not change the musical interaction, so the gameplay is identical.It's easy to pick up and play, and pretty enjoyable. There's good replayability in theory, but I don't think the shooting is varied enough to come back to it regularly after finishing off all the challenges. Audiosurf has more gameplay options to keep things fresh, but this is still an enjoyable shooter with all the DLC. I'd say $10 USD for the full package would be a great deal, so 30% off everything is pretty fair when that happens.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 18, 2010
												Depending on how intense or soft your music collection is, Beat Hazard is one crazy game.Intense music pushes the limit by adding fast-moving asteroids along with blood-thirsty ships out to destroy you.You try to score as many points as possible while playing your song. If you make it through, you'll move on to the next. Score point and your rank will increase. Every time you reach a new level, there will be favorable bonuses which make you earn points in larger quantities much faster.As your music gets more intense, so do your weapons nad the amount of enemies. The flashing lights may be disorienting after a while, but luckily there's a relax mode like in aaAAaa.The powerups really help you, but I recommend that you clear out the enemies until you go for the powerups.The boss battles are cool too. Depending on your tracks you're playing, it may produce two mini bosses or one big boss.If it goes on sale, I recommend this for everyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												I have a thing for music games, geometry wars, and asteroids.  Effectively, Beat Hazard is a ombination of all of those things.Because the gameplay is generated by your music your mileage may vary by a lot.  This isn't like Audiorsurf, where each song is playable if boring: certain songs are not playable at all.  The reason behind this is that sometimes nothing can happen in the song you're playing, or worse, monsters might spawn just before you hit a slow point.  The biggest issue with this game is that the music not only dictates monster spawns but also has a direct influence on your basic attack: You will not be able to kill things during quieter parts of the song.  This is absolutely game breaking at times.Still, if you know that you can avoid the problem, and honestly I really like the gameplay.  Beat Hazard has changed a lot over the years, to the point that I don't really recognize it from when I first played it.  There's an overall level up system and some perks, but they're not so important to the gameplay (at least that's my opinion).Unlike audiosurf this is hardly a chillout game.  This isn't something that I'll boot up when I just want to listen to music and maybe have something to do in the background: the gameplay gets pretty intense at times.  It's not necessarily difficult, but it does remind me of how harrowing geometry wars can get.I like this game but I don't play it very often, and gameplay isn't so different between songs that it feels unique.  For the most part each song plays out pretty similarly, which is good and bad.At the end of the day I think you should have this in your library.Oh, but the ♥♥♥♥ing ad that pops up as you're closing the game?  The one that reverses the accept and cancel buttons?  That screen can ♥♥♥♥ off.  Press A to exit, press a to exit, PRESS A TO GO BACK TO THE ♥♥♥♥ING MAIN MENU AND START AGAIN.  Gets me every god damned time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												I'm a huge fan of music in games or games that revolve around music. Recently i started to play Beat Hazard again and purchased the Shadow Operations Unit DLC.GameSo what is this game about. You choose a spaceship, the basic one or the different ships from the Shadow Operations Unit DLC. Then you choose a song, either your own songs or the different ones from the radio stations provided by Beat Hazard. The gameplays consists of you floating around, shooting different enemys to the beat of your favorite songs. There are  four more different game modes.Standart: you basically choose a song and play it.Boss Rush: again you choose a song, but instead of normal enemys you fight only bosses. You have a timer for every boss, meaning if you take your time you can easily have up to 4-5 bosses on screen. Also dont worry the song isn't going to be repeated. You choose a song. From there every song in that folder will be played.Survival: Choose a song where you start off from. After that you basically have to survive wave after wave, like the name of this game mode already suggest. Like in boss rush you start with the song you chose, after that every song in the same folder will be played.Chill out: The same as survival but without lives and scores. You just keep playing until you have enough :DAlso like in boss rush you start with the song you chose, after that every song in the same folder will be played.Perks: While playing songs you collect money that you can use to buy those perks. There are various perks to enhance your overall score for every song, perks for different weapons and shields. The last thing you can unlock with the money are 2 more difficulties.Shadow Operations Unit DLC.The DLC adds different spaceships to the game which all have their own missions. Per spaceship you have 3 missions. You rank up everytime you complete one of those missions. ConclusionBeat Hazard is a really fun game, gameplay is simple but entertaining. I spend 50 hours on this game,  getting the achivements, play the different gamemodes, play multiplayer with friends. The only thing i would have to mention is the DLC. Personally i dont think its worth the 5€. You only get a few different spaceships which, lets be honest, all have the same missions: "collect this x times"  "Kill x enemy x times"  "get x points on x songs on x difficulty". The ships are kinda interesting and fun to play but i really don't think its worth 5€ considering that you can get spaceships from the steam workshop for free..Nevertheless Beat Hazard is a really good game and will keep you entertained for lots of hours, even without the dlc.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Beat Hazard is Geometry Wars, but less geometery and more... lights.  Lights everywhere.  Don't play this game if you have a history of Epilepsy.Beat Hazard is a simple game of moving and shooting.  Imagine Galaga with an ♥♥♥♥♥♥ of music that the player can import or choose from a variety of music that Cold Beam Games has for it.You control a ship equipped with a laser gun and super bombs.  These can be upgraded later.  Simply point and click to fire your gun.  As you destroy ships, you can collect score multipliers, and bombs.  Along with these you can pick up Volume and Power that adds devastating power to your guns.  As you progress, you encounter a ton of bosses that add challenge and variety to the game.All in all, Beat Hazard deserves more than a mere 70/100 Metascore.  There is very satisfying music with more satisfying guns, and progressive upgrades that add fresh twists to the game amps the replay value.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Awesome music-based shmup!The pace and graphics of the game depends entirely on the music playing in the background, so pump in some techno/metal track to get some seriously challenging game ahead, or put in your favorite classical piano piece if you want a more relaxing game session.You can compete for the highest scores on the leaderboards. You can also play cooperatively (Co-op) or competitively (PvP) with a friend, it's extremely fun, especially if you both have the same taste in music.This really is a fun game to pickup and play just a song (or a full album!) every once in a while.I highly recommend getting the Beat Hazard: Ultra DLC (it adds new weapons, new bosses, new game modes, etc.). But since the DLC changes the core gameplay so much, the game still let you choose to play either the Classic or Ultra version on startup!However, I would definitely not recommend this game to people prone to epilepsy. *winks* *winks* *winks*

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												While i may not get any seizure it still gives my eyes a acid trip.Astroids and music mashed into one,and your own tracks to boot or if you do not own a lot of music you can stream internet radio! Bonus if you love Christmas music they have achievements for that.I love the game it is a good way to relax and listen to music at the same time without it getting annoying like in most games.You can also just let it play music and enjoy the visual if your into that sort of thing,i sometimes double it as a music player.Pros for Beat Hazard classic+Fast paced action with a old school feel for Astroid games+Smooth game play and neat visual effects+Ships to unlock or download from workshop+It is a blast with a friend+It gives you a reason to annoy your neighbors,crank it up!!Cons for Beat Hazard Classic- Can only select songs by folder or individual no options for custom play list- Wish it had an option to customize what type of enimies you face- Can be hard to keep track of things on screen when things get crazy- Wish it had more play styles like Ultra doesPros for Ulta +Fast paced action with a old school feel for Astroid games+Smooth game play and neat visual effects amped up even more+Ships to unlock or download from workshop+Perks system and a hanger to check out your ships with +Last FM built into game+Keyboard Configuration+It is a blast with a friend+Can play the same tracks with friends as long as you both have the same one+It gives you a reason to annoy your neighbors,crank it up!!Cons for Ulta-Can be even harder to keep track of things going on screen even when you turn down visuals-Can have issues with saves due to syncing with cloud issues,i had to delete my save to get it start after re-installing game to play it again,lost progress because of it.- Level 5 badge to unlock a ship:ship is cosmetic but still have to spend money to reach level 5- Can only select songs by folder or individual no options for custom play list- Wish it had an option to customize what type of enimies you face would love to face different ships depening on song and so on but eh again a mior gripe.Make sure you enable Steam cloud servies before launching Ultra or it will just loop at loading screen,why this is not fixed or an issue is beyound me but it is a minor gripe.Over all i  love the game and bought this game because i have to face the fact that  i am terrible at music rhythm games and i tried Audio Surf and i just did not care for it,I checked this game out and watched the video and it reminded me of Retro Evovled only with my own music,so i bought it and do not regret it one bit.Then Humble had a bundle that had the Ultra content and i had to buy it and love Ultra also.Though i do have issues at times of keeping track of everything going on screen and die because my ship blends in with everything else even with visual turned all the way down.I know this is not a issue for everyone but i did find a lot people did have the same issues and asked if more could be done,but nothing has and fell on deaf earsThat being siad that is a minor thing and does not take away from the fun but it can take away from the competitive side knowing you died not by your mistake but by merely losing track of your ship because to much visual effects.In the end regardless if you like astroids or music i think you will love this game if you love music based games.Also if you love Retro Evolved and would love to play something akin to it with your own music then you must gets this!!Anyhow i know i am not always the best at making reviews but i am trying to improve on that.I hope at least one person finds this helpful,Enjoy the game,have fun and stay safe!

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												Beat Hazard is a very cool arcade game based off of the older game "Asteroids" but there is one very good reason why I do not recommend this game.In terms of graphics, performance, gameplay, and the DLC's such as "Shadow Operations Unit", the game is great. However, the one major flaw that gives me reason to not recommend this game is due to the repetition in the gameplay.When I first got Beat Hazard, it was a very fun game. I spent a bit of time on it, leveled up a lot, and a few days later I bought the Shadow Operations Unit DLC. Now, a month or two after I initially downloaded Beat Hazard, I never open the game anymore because it plainly becomes boring-- the gameplay is always the same: shoot and survive. Yes, there's goals such as those with the Shadow Operations Unit, but that doesn't change how repetitive the gameplay gets after a very short time. The gameplay is designed well, but it needs more variety, options, gamemodes and so on to prevent it from getting old as quick as it did for me.I personally find the game very boring now, due to how incredibly repetitive this game is. In my opinion, the $9.99 I spent on it was not well spent, and unfortunately due to my 3.7 hours on record I am unable to refund the game. If the developer were to add more gamemodes and variety to the gameplay so it isn't the same old thing, I would love to get back into this game again. I could also settle for a lower price assuming the repetition in the gameplay does not change. But until any of that happens, I probably won't be spending much if any time on Beat Hazard.Thanks for reading my review and I hope any possible viewers take it into consideration before purchasing this game.Ciao!

												I'm going to be pretty harsh here tbh.I played a little bit of it after buying it on sale, figured I'd give it ago.I was hoping for something like AudioSurf only with an arcadey space shooter twist.What I got, was far from what I was hoping, and it was very underwhelming.First, I stumbled around trying to find music, it starts with music I guess from the games built in library or something?So I went into options to find my own music, okay, i need to index it, and this was the first negative for the game.When you have over 2,000 songs in your downloads folder, indexing songs like this over having it as a browsing thing like what Audiosurf does makes it take a very, very, very, very, very very long time for someone who has lots of music, I ended up getting tired of waiting for it to finishing indexing the music at around the 4,500 song mark, this is not even 10 percent or less of my library as I believe last count I had over 20,000 songs.It also appeared, to find a song, you need to browse through them using the "N" key, which is ENTIRELY impractical for such a huge amount of songs.Alright, so maybe the actual game will offer what I am hoping for, so I went to play one of Abigor's songs since it was a very fast song. I was hoping to see some very fast gameplay and colors and flashes all over the place.HHAHAHA... Nope. You're basically just floating around in space with random objects spawning at you and shooting you, the song did not dictate how fast the gameplay was so it was basically just playing in the background.Oh, and to make it worse, you need to pick up powerups for extra volume..Very misleading if you ask me.I do not recommend this game if you are looking for games similar to Audiosurf as this, is DEFINITELY, not it.0/10

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												Two recommendations are posted here, one for the Shadow OPs DLC and my original one for the Beat Hazard Ultra.Shadow Operations recommendation (18 Apr 2014):A very fun DLC that lets you create your own ships, upload the ships to the workshop, and download other player's ships from the workshop. When creating your ship, you can choose from several attributes such as the ship's size, how fast/slow it accelerates, top speed, how fast/slow it decelerates, how strong the bullets are, how fast the bullets move, position of the guns, whether or not you repel or attract perks, how many beams (1-3), and more.  You also get to set up to three missions for your creation so you can make them easy, hard, or a mix.  As you gain higher ranks, you unlock some nice cosmetic attributes such as flares and engine thrust colour. It really is a lot of fun and it gives you new ways to enjoy Beat Hazard.Any song with the Shadow OPs icon next to it has a chance to spawn what you need for missions. Additional info from a quote from Starg: "The 'play random track' and 'one I've not played before' will also automatically choose a song that fits the current mission criteria."Original recommendation I wrote for the game (23 July 2013):I bought this before the sale ended, after having played the demo, and I have to say, it's pretty damn fun. I explode a lot but that's part of the fun for me, destruction to all!!! mwahahaha. The game is wicked cool and I'm glad I bought the complete package so that I have all the nuts & bolts to fiddle with. It's interesting trying out different songs from my computer, some of them get so intense that there's so much going on on the screen that I lose track of, well, everything. Some of my songs have lulls in them where I'm sitting in space twiddling my thumbs getting the Daredevil (and the other one, I forget the name), counting up. I've only played around 26 minutes so far, as far as the in-game counter goes, but it's been fun.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												Honestly, this is an amazing game. I barely know where to start.As a gamer, this is probably my new favorite way to enjoy my music. The gist of this one is that you can select your own music files to "play", which adds personality and variety to your game. It works like so: You choose a directory where you keep your music, and you can select any and all music on your computer to play with. Once you select a track, the game loads up and you're in. It should be noted that the visual effects are seizure-inducing (the game warns you this when it starts up), but this is not a problem for most people. I got past it after my first couple of games.Playing a certain music file is like playing a different "level", albeit with very similar enemies. Most of the time you will fight a "boss" ship towards the end of the level that will have a large amount of health and some very dangerous weapons. During the fight, small enemy ships may attack you as well. The best way to deal with the boss is to try and outmaneuver its weapons while keeping it under your concentrated fire.It is kind of a difficult game, and it resembles a generic arcade shooter. You have a small ship with a decent amount of firepower and a set number of lives to begin with. Taking a single hit will cause you to lose a life and most of your powerups, but some of the lost powerups drop in the middle of the screen in a cluster and you will have a few brief moments of invulnerability, allowing you to pick them up when you respawn. Power and Volume are your best friends in this game; they increase the amount of guns you can have going at a time, and the intensity of the damage you deal out, respectively. You will notice that the visual effects as well as your damage increase quite a bit when heavy bass or loud, sharp tones play in your music. This makes it ideal for dubstep and metal in my opinion, but as long as your music has a sick beat and a high enough volume, you should be fine. The visuals can be distracting at times, such as when your music becomes more intense and everything gets two or three times brighter. This makes it harder to see what your enemies are doing, but picking up on certain visual cues will help. One such cue is that one of the main indestructible projectiles that is fired at your ship is always red in color, and is always round.Even if you don't want to play the game, you can use the game's built-in visualizer in "Chill Out" mode to just listen to music and watch your screen do its thing. It actually is pretty relaxing.I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys listening to their music, or even just likes arcade shooters. In my opinion, it is worth the money whether you want to blow stuff up or just kick back and relax. If you're lucky enough to pick it up while it's on sale, it is a total steal. As long as you don't run out of music, you will not run out of fun with this game.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												I listen to a ton of music. I have a huge music collection, and I love games that allow me to use my own music for gameplay. Thus far, this game is the most fun, the most visually striking, and the most exciting. That's not to say that other titles that use your own music for gameplay are bad, that's just to say that this one does it the best. It's a simple idea, you're in space, you're in a starship, and you're killing enemies and blowing up rocks, but you're doing it with flashing rave lights and your own music controlling the ebb and flow of the entire game. This isn't just another space shooter, it's not just another music game that goes with the beat, it is truly spontaneous artwork in a visual medium - and it's done better here than anywhere else. Though not the most original idea, it is definitely the idea perfected. It's predecessors and the games that came after it with a simple concept aren't bad, but they aren't this good. The (very) recent release of a new DLC with more options and playability really caught my attention after not playing the game for a few months, now I don't know how I'm going to sleep tonight. 9.5/10 - easily. Worth twice the price, highly underrated.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Tags : Casual - Twitch - Music Driven           Sidescroll ShootEmUp/Bullet HellWhenever I test out a ShootEmUp from some greenlit indie game, I always think... does this have anything to offer that Beat Hazard doesnt do better. 90% of the time at least the answer is no.Beat Hazard is an excellent ShootEmUp, with the music driven twist that adjusts the number of ennemies as well as your rate of auto-fire to the rate of the music playing. Its not always perfectly spot on but for the mos part this feature works very well.Being able to play with your own music is very enjoyable, and helps give each game its own tone and sense of progression which otherwise would sometimes be lacking certainly and become repetitive much quickerI am not very good at ShootEmUps but there are a lot of game modes from just casually going through with fewer ennemies to rogue-like permadeath style games with much harsh victory conditionsI find not cranking the difficulty to the max is usually better as your own music can become distracting and this is not the kind of game that is forgiving at higher difficulties to distractionA con is that the flashy effects are sometimes a little over the top and can obfuscate a lot of the screen and even daze you quite a bit especially on higher difficulties where you spam heavy bombsI would recommend this game. I see it as one of the few references in the genre and I am glad it is in my collection

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
 My new arcade favorite First of all I bought this game at the summer sale for 1,39€. I don't think I would buy it if I had to pay over 5€, but let's get into it.The download took about two minutes, and I could enjoy the game right away. I picked up my Xbox 360 controller and sat down after I had a quick coffee. I was met with the most flashing and colourful startup screen ever, and even the menus were pretty intence. This game is not for people with epilepsy, so don't even try it if you think you have it. Now the menus and settings was pretty easy to navigate, as you would expect from an arcade shooter.The musicThe game came with a lot of music, but it clarely wasn't my taste, so you probably have to download some yourself. It can be hard if you don't have much technical knowledge though, as you have to browse your folders and find your music manually.Anyways, I bought the Mega Bundle, so I could play m4a files from my iTunes folders. But you can actually just convert your iTunes music to the mp3 format to play them, so the DLC s pretty useless. I did miss a Soundcloud implementation though, it was pretty good in Audiosurf 2.The gameSo I selected 'Wake Me Up' by Avicii, and gave it a go. The start was very similar to the good old Atari game, Astroids. Big astroids came flying by and became smaller pieces upon destruction, as you would expect. But after some time, the game became something pretty different.Lots of spaceships attacked my ship and performed the old art of kamikaze. Most ships doesn't shoot projectiles, but they try to destroy my ship in many different ways. Some ships gather around me and try to squash me, some try to pull me like a vacuum cleaner and there is even a ship that will try to choak me like a king cobra. So there is obviously a big variety of enemies.The best part was probably how the game adopted to different songs. I could play almost any song I wanted and the gameplay would still be awesome.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Pros and ConsPros:Fun and addictive gameplayGreat variety of perks and powerupsCool colours and graphic effectsMany levels, unlocks and achievements Local and online cross-platform co opNo bugs/glitches (after my experience)Pros:No Soundcloud implementationToo fast to level up at the startA little too pricey for an arcade shooterUseless iTunes & m4a file support DLC----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall rating: 9/10

Might be a bit much for some people, and it's definitely best consumed in small chunks, but it's super enjoyable in my opinion. content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Beat Hazard, A game that is literally "Powered by your music". Beat hazard is a game in which you pilot a space ship and avoid incoming enemy attacks from missiles and lasers to rockets and crashing. Your weapons are powered by your music as well. Have a silent song, and your gun will be weak, have a loud song such as heavy metal, and you will be blasting enemies from all directions, but sometimes, you need more than just big guns. Obatin powerups such as superbomb to eradicate enemies or get out of a sticky situation. This game has inspired me to dive deeper into the music industry. The game also has a Co-op or Head-to-Head feature. Team up with your friends in taking enemies down, or see who can take on more, and rise above all others. But there are some enemies, that cannot be taken on alone....My Overall rating for this game  -  8/10

Posted: November 25, 2013
												If you like to shut off your lights and stare into the glowing screen while a zillion colors flash at epileptic seizure inducing speeds while playing your music at levels that will probably give you permanent hearing damage, then this game is for youuuuuu. Load up your MP3s and the game will hurl space junk and enemy ships for you to destroy without mercy. Collect powerups like Volume Up and Power Up to make your music louder and your shots bigger and more powerful.You've also got sort of a levelling system where you can unlock abilities like Shields, Homing Rockets and a concentrated blast of energy. If that's not enough for you, you can set the effect level to 200% and enjoy the burning feeling of flashing lights into your eyes. It's even got online and local multiplayer to boot.I can't really think of any glaring negatives to the game. It'll run on anything, runs with keyboard and mouse or controller if you so desire, and even supports online livestreaming play, so you can play forever on your favorite internet radio station.Buy it. Like, right now.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												If you want to know what this game is think asteroids on steroids to your favourite music tracks. This is my go-to game whenever I just want to zone out and kill some time playing something while listening to music, but don't feel like starting a new game or concentrating on a story, etc. This is my Tetris.This perhaps isn't the best game if you only want to kill a *little* time, since it plays your music collection (and therefore has the best sound track ever), everytime you say "I'll quit after this round!" it goes and picks yet another great track and you end up saying "Well... maybe after this one!"What I love about this game is that can be customised to suit your mood - harder difficulties are *HARD*, easier difficulties are easy. The intensity of the game depends on the intensity of the music track you play. You can unlock perks and assign them to help in different ways. After a high score? Put your perks into score multipliers and sacrifice the extra weapons. Feel like a challenge? Assign your perks to weapons and bump the difficulty up (I'm actually pretty good at Suicidal difficulty now ;). Want to just take it easy? Lower the difficulty and put on some relaxing music.The game actually comes with a decent selection of music from a range of genres, which I discovered while unlocking the Music Tour achievement. Of course it has a fair bit of electronic music, which you would expect from a game like this, but I very happy to see it actually has some decent alternative rock & metal tracks as well. It can also stream music from a number of Internet radio stations (no idea if it's possible to add more), but of course you will really want to bring your own music collection to enjoy this game the most. For me, that's European style Symphonic Power Metal \m/The perks can be a bit of a grind to unlock, and even more so to fully upgrade them. Unlocking them just takes score, but upgrading them can only be done by picking up in game money - and that only drops $10 at a time. That's not really a problem as the low-mid levels are fairly cheap and is all you need as long as you aren't trying to play on Suicidal difficulty, but maxing them out does take a fair while.Let's talk weapons. Like most asteroids type games you have a generic laser that can be upgraded by picking up POWer ups. This one is actually pretty good - it has a decent spread and can take out a large number of enemies pretty quickly. The unique thing about this game is the intensity of your weapons also depends on the intensity of the music - picking up VOL+ powerups increases the volume, making your weapons more powerful, but at the same time it also spawns more enemies and makes them faster.Your second weapon is of course some kind of super bomb, also known as the "OH GOD TOO MANY ENEMIES!!!" panic button to take out most of the nearby enemies and give you a few seconds of invaulnerability. Then you have the reflective shield, homing micro missiles and the Ultra Beam to quickly eradicate a large group of enemies in a given direction. I love that none of these weapons feel like duplicates and they all have their place - knowing which one to use when becomes very important in the higher difficulties.You remember back in the nineties how games used to have warnings on the box & the first page of the manual not to play them if you suffer from epilepsy? Well, I do. Anyway - I think this game actually means it, it uses a lot of very intense strobing visuals which (other than causing epilectic siezures) can make it pretty hard to see incoming projectiles - when I first started playing half the time I couldn't see what had killed me. The visuals can be toned down (or increased to epic proportions!!!), but personally I kept them on 100% and just got used to them.If you are going to buy this, get the Beat Hazard Ultra DLC - some of the stuff I mentioned here is specific to that DLC and the base game does not have a huge amount of variety in terms of enemies, weapons, etc. The only reason not to get the Ultra DLC is to try it out a bit and see if you like it. As soon as you are convinced, buy the Ultra DLC.I've been playing this on and off over the last two years. Finally managed to unlock all the achievements - it was a long run, but totally worth it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												If you want to listen to music, but also want to occupy yourself while you do so, Beat Hazard is an alright game.The game is very simple. It is a two-dimensional, top-down, static shooter. You pilot a ship on the screen while music plays, a lot of colors flash and strobe on the screen while enemies pour in from the edges trying to destroy your ship. Your mission is to stay alive for the duration of whatever song is playing and get the highest score you can. The flashing colors, lights, enemies etc., go along with your music. So if you have a slow song playing most everything will be going slowly (this includes your shots, though not your ship) and if the tempo suddenly picks up, so does everything else. Occasionally a boss enemy will come on the screen to fight you. There are also various power-ups you can grab as you defeat enemies.Your score is tallied over time and added into what is essentially an experience bar. Every time you go up a level you can choose a new perk to add to your perk list. You can then go to the perk list and activate a small number of perks to use in each match. The perks are simple things such as score multipliers or more interesting things like different weapons (micro seeking missiles, a massive laser beam, a relector shield).Music:Some music is included, if you're into dubstep, and some online radio stations are included as well if you'd prefer to stream music. If you have music on your computer you can easily add folders or individual files into the games library.A warning:If you are susceptible to strobe effects and flashing lights, etc., I would not recommend this game. You can lower the effects by up to 50%, but even at 50% I often find myself having difficulty seeing anything on the screen due to the effects. That is really the only negative aspect of the game to me.The game can be a bit repetitive as the locations never change, it's just always the same box of seizure lights and the same set of enemies. I enjoy the game because I have difficulty listening to music and focusing on other things at the same time, so this is a way for me to listen to music, but still keep myself occupied with something.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2010
												This is a fantastic game IF you like gaming to music.  It reminds me a lot of Asteroids, only far more difficult, musical and psychodelic.  If you're going to play, make sure you aren't prone to epiplectic seizures.  The bright colors and flashing effects might induce a seizure.  I wouldn't play if you've got a migraine of headache in general.  With the possible exception of Audiosurf, I'd say this is the most entertaining music-based game on Steam.  There are numerous achievements to gain and I believe you can play it two-player.  I think it's local co-op, so that means you'll have to use the same PC.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Beat Hazard is Asteroids on crack and set to music. It can get quite challenging and is also a good bit of fun, allowing you to pipe in your own tunes that will affect the progression of the level. Everything about the game is well done, but it feels a bit too thrown together; and again, in many respects an Asteroids clone. The algorithm that spawns enemies based on what music you choose likewise seems a bit questionable, and many songs I tried out didn't really elicit battles that I felt fit with the rhythm of the music. I'd end up lazily floating about picking off weak enemies during adrenaline pumping electric guitar solos.I wouldn't say it's a bad game, but I don't think I'd really recommend it to people either. It's a cool concept, but what was delivered was merely passable; nothing to get terribly excited about.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2011
													Photosensitive Seizure WarningA very small percentage of people may experience a seizure when exposed to certain visual images, including flashing lights or patterns that may appear in video games. Even people who have no history of seizures or epilepsy may have an undiagnosed condition that can cause these "photosensitive epileptic seizures" while watching video games.These seizures may have a variety of symptoms, including lightheadedness, altered vision, eye or face twitching, jerking or shaking of arms or legs, disorientation, confusion, or momentary loss of awareness. Seizures may also cause loss of consciousness or convulsions that can lead to injury from falling down or striking nearby objects.Immediately stop playing and consult a doctor if you experience any of these symptoms. Parents should watch for or ask their children about the above symptoms - children and teenagers are more likely than adults to experience these seizures.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Beat Hazard is a twin-stick shooter that generates levels based upon intensity of certain levels of music. You choose a track, then proceed to fights hordes of enemies until the selected tracks plays out. During that time you pick up score multipliers, bombs, volume uppers, and power uppers. Every now and then bosses will appear. These are much larger than standard enemies. Some times you can even get through songs without ever seeing a boss, but that just depends on the intensity of the selected track I guess.I love everything about this game, except the lack of leaderboards for actual artist/song titles. Yes, I just wish the leaderboards were more like Audiosurf, that way I could be more competetive in a game that is just screaming to have people compete for specific scores on songs and several difficulty settings.But that's essentially it. It's Robotron combined with Audiosurf. Online is fun too, assuming you snatch the Ultra DLC. If you have a friend who has similar music taste, you can index your whole music library and play the same songs assuming you're both competent enough to be snobs about correct track info. You wouldn't want to end up playing completely songs, would you?I highly recommend this for music snobs, and arcade junkies. I also highly recommend the Ultra DLC to go with this to. It really brings some more life into the base game.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2011
												You can turn your whole collection of music into a raving shooting experience! The gameplay is very simple to grasp, yet enjoyable nonetheless. Causal gamers can kick back and blast away at waves and waves of enemies while enjoying the raving light-show to their favorite songs, while hardcore gamers can go all out on the harder difficulty settings with the amount of challenge and eye-bleeding intensity this game has to offer. And it gets even better with the addition of a downloadable expansion (Beat Hazard Ultra) that improves on the game's music synchronization, adds new gameplay modes, new enemies, new weapons to play around with, and ONLINE PLAY! I definitely recommend people to pick this one up, it's probably the best $16-12 you could spend on a game. Just be warned, your eyes may not handle the raving beast that this game is.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												The base game of Beat Hazard is excelent. Er...no. The base game of Beat Hazard is GOOD. Screen-obscuring lighting effects that blind you from being able to actually see the action even on the lowest possible setting, occasionally unfair hitbox issues (which result in an enemy's "tell" effectively lying to you), and a few generally aggravating game behaviours - most notably the AI patterns of certain bosses - prevent it from being "excellent". Nonetheless, it can be quite entertaining, and being powered by your own music means that it automatically has the best soundtrack ever...all your favourite songs! There's a fair variety of perks, which means you can tailor your ship to your play style, whatever that may be, and if you're the competitive sort, the leaderboards can provide you with goals to strive for, even if it's just being the best out of your own circle of friends. That you can use an internet radio station if you get bored of your own music is a nice added touch as well, which can add hours more play time.That said, a special mention needs to go out to the Shadow Operations DLC. DO NOT BUY THE SHADOW OPERATIONS DLC, UNLESS YOU ARE BOTH A HARDCORE COMPLETIONIST, AND LOOKING FOR NEW GOALS TO EXTEND THE LIFE OF THE GAME. Otherwise, it's just not woth it. I cannot stress this enough. Shadow Ops. adds a lot more "challenge" to the game, in the form of new "missions" with arbitrarily difficult requirements, but doesn't do much to change the overall gameplay. Even with the new ships, the "fun factor" just isn't much improved. Unless you love pitting yourself against massochistic difficulty, you're going to more than likely be disappointed. There might be some entertainment in the user-created ships, but by and large they are either completely overpowered, just a reference to some series or other, or "lulzy" (read as "deliberately stupid"), and still don't add much to the game, unless you are easily amused, a serious Star Trek/Battlestar Galactica/Touhou/Etc... nerd, or both. Even as cheap as it is, you should really just consider the DLC to be nothing more than a generous tip to the developers, and treat it as such...only buying it if you really want to give them more money for the sake of it.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2011
												You can turn your whole collection of music into a raving shooting experience! The gameplay is very simple to grasp, yet enjoyable nonetheless. Causal gamers can kick back and blast away at waves and waves of enemies while enjoying the raving light-show to their favorite songs, while hardcore gamers can go all out on the harder difficulty settings with the amount of challenge and eye-bleeding intensity this game has to offer. And it gets even better with the addition of a downloadable expansion (Beat Hazard Ultra) that improves on the game's music synchronization, adds new gameplay modes, new enemies, new weapons to play around with, and ONLINE PLAY! I definitely recommend people to pick this one up, it's probably the best $16-12 you could spend on a game. Just be warned, your eyes may not handle the raving beast that this game is.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2011
												Note: Below exists an update. Here's the review from 2011-10-18: Can be played solo or coop/competitively over the 'net.  Both players must have the same song (length and metadata must be the same) locally, or they can use last.fm or another online music stream.  Different songs are supposed to produce the same experience each time, if the song file and the game settings are the same. Beat Hazard is a top-down two-stick (or 1 keyboard, or mouse+keyboard) shooter with a lot of variation. The variations become even more diverse when you consider that the gameplay changes depending on what musical track you're playing in the background. The degree to which the music affects it can be adjusted, and the frenetic visuals can be turned up or down independently. The various Beat Hazard Ultra (the only version still being developed AFAIK) perks and weapons change how the player must react to the various enemies (depending on which the player has purchased (cash is dropped by slain enemies) and enabled--I'mouttaroomhere--Update 2014-06-25: People will call the visuals seizure-inducing. That seems like a good description when describing overwhelming visuals, but it's literal only for people who have seizures triggered by the visuals common to this game. I imagine there are some who have photosensitive seizures who will not be bothered by this game, or only by the visuals prompted by certain songs. I have had stress-induced seizures, but I've never been photosensitive in the slightest, to this or any other visual stimulation.This is an awesome game, with many awesome things added to it since my first review a few years ago!Note (2014-10-08): The main game's title appears to have reverted to the original Beat Hazard (some months ago).

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												In short: This game is astroids on LSD, and I love it.  As with any good review, lets start with the postives.  First, this game looks quite pretty, especialy on a nice screen the colors are vivid and suit the game nicely.  Second, Its fun, truthfuly this is the most important part of a game.  It has a nice face paced gameplay (least with the songs that I have put through it).  It gets quite chalenging once you unlock the higher teir skill ranks, im not usaly a fan of skill unlocks, but I got the highest in like half an hour so i guess its fine.  Its crazy fun to have your screen filled with colors, not knowing which are things to avoid or is simply your laser of death, you might not like that but i find that it adds to the excitment.ok, its cons time!  The game is a pretty slopy Xbox port, they didnt even remove the button promps, but this game feels more like its supposed to be played with a controler, especialy with the keyboard scheem and split screen (Yes, split screen!).  This is the worst part of the game: you have to buy a DLC, sure ill buy a good DLC like Tinny tinas assult on dragon keep, or a good Bioshock DLC, but I dont want to pay money to unlock a game mode (boss rush and online multiplayer) the DLC also unlocks various diffrent types of ships and the steam workshop.  It also bugs you when you try to exit the game telling you to buy the DLC.  This is really my biggest grip though, all in all this game is a blast to play.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												It's been on my wishlist for a while and it was gifted to me recently - and unfortunately it's a lot less fun than I'd imagined it to be! I'm biased for these kinds of games since I like challenging arcade games and music-powered games, so you'd think I'd like this one. Yes, well... not really.(Mind you, I'm in no way photosensitive like some others who have left a negative review on this game have been, and I can handle rapid flashing just fine, but if it becomes gameplay-inhibiting, then the design is absolutely flawed.)Problems with the game:* Often screen-filling visual effects that prevent you from seeing what is going on. You can't dodge bullets if you can't see them...* Overboard on the "flashy sparkly fireworks" effects. I mean, way overboard, and then some. It's not "cool", it's not "attractive", and it gives you a headache if you're not careful.* The music plays very soft. I have properly balanced music files and they simply don't play at a decent volume in the game - for a music-focused game you'd expect the audio component to be at least adequate and give priority to proper playback without having to amplify it into clipping ranges.* Scoring is meaningless: levels are random, so what rewards you get and points you score for a song is not dependent on the music at all. Score is determined by chance and not by skill, as a result.* Music-based firepower will favor even, loud songs. You get a dynamic song with breaks and softer parts and you're pretty much at the mercy of whatever random fleets of ships are thrown your way with no way to fight them off. And woe if you hit a quiet spot when a boss is thrown at you. Good luck with that, get ready for a grind.* Screen-filling visual effects that.. Ohwait, I already said that. :P Yes, it's a problem. Worthy of mentioning twice. It kills the ability to properly play a "bullet hell" game. Period.

												If you ever played a game like Asteroids or  any other space shooter then you should generally understand Beat Hazard, however, Beat Hazard has 2 main things that no other space shooter has.The first this to know is that as it says, this game is powered by your music, the more songs you have, the more potential for fun this game has, your weapons power, enemy strength and attack patterns are determined by the music.The second thing you should know is this game uses high levels of strobe lights that respond to the music, this game should not be played if you are suseptable to any sort of a seizure from flickering, blinking or flashing lights.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												It's been on my wishlist for a while and it was gifted to me recently - and unfortunately it's a lot less fun than I'd imagined it to be! I'm biased for these kinds of games since I like challenging arcade games and music-powered games, so you'd think I'd like this one. Yes, well... not really.(Mind you, I'm in no way photosensitive like some others who have left a negative review on this game have been, and I can handle rapid flashing just fine, but if it becomes gameplay-inhibiting, then the design is absolutely flawed.)Problems with the game:* Often screen-filling visual effects that prevent you from seeing what is going on. You can't dodge bullets if you can't see them...* Overboard on the "flashy sparkly fireworks" effects. I mean, way overboard, and then some. It's not "cool", it's not "attractive", and it gives you a headache if you're not careful.* The music plays very soft. I have properly balanced music files and they simply don't play at a decent volume in the game - for a music-focused game you'd expect the audio component to be at least adequate and give priority to proper playback without having to amplify it into clipping ranges.* Scoring is meaningless: levels are random, so what rewards you get and points you score for a song is not dependent on the music at all. Score is determined by chance and not by skill, as a result.* Music-based firepower will favor even, loud songs. You get a dynamic song with breaks and softer parts and you're pretty much at the mercy of whatever random fleets of ships are thrown your way with no way to fight them off. And woe if you hit a quiet spot when a boss is thrown at you. Good luck with that, get ready for a grind.* Screen-filling visual effects that.. Ohwait, I already said that. :P Yes, it's a problem. Worthy of mentioning twice. It kills the ability to properly play a "bullet hell" game. Period.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												My only complaint, is that music starts quiet, and to get the music really pumping loud, you have to either turn up your speakers or simply be good at the game... I sadly cannot be bothered playing enough to learn how to not die, ever, soooo I think I'll just go ahead and leave it at this.Beat Hazard, is probably the best 'music simulator' ever. As a game that takes your music collection, and makes it 'playable' I still think Beat Hazard is the best. It's challenging, yes, but it's really just an eye test. After a while your eyes get lazy, and tired, and you'll stop noticing things. Vital things. Like bullets coming for you. Unlike certain bullet hell games, this isn't really a bullet hell game. It's more like Asteroids. You need to avoid the enemy space ships which seem hell bent on ramming you, and all the scrap asteroids, which break apart when shot.If you're looking for a gimmicky game which takes advantage of YOUR music collection, and NOT the potentially sub-par music of the indie game itself, and for SURE your own tastes, here you go, I think this will whet your appetite better than other games, such as Audiosurf, which although fun, is far too easy for my tastes.

												This game is basically Asteroids for the 21st century.  Twin stick shooter that reacts really well to the music track playing. content:
Posted: December 7, 2010
												Beat Hazard is one of my absolute favorite indie titles/procedural music games. It's got the gameplay and visceral feel of a classic arcade shooter, with the endless replayability of levels that are generated according to the songs you feed the game. It's made extra-addictive through a rank system (with powerups/enhancements as you earn more ranks), high-score boards, and achievements.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Beat Hazard is a unique shoot'em up. The levels are the songs on your computer. How does it work though? When you start playing, you don't really see how it goes at the rythm of your songs. But after some time playing, you'll start to realize that it really does go at the rythm of your songs. It's hard to notice though, since Beat Hazard require quite a lot of focus on the ennemies and incoming projectiles. Despite that, Beat Hazard is a hardcore and very addicting game. If you love shooters, this is an excellent game for you.HOWEVER, I do have to give some warnings. DO NOT BUY IF YOU SUFFER FROM EPILIPSY. This game has A LOT of flashing lights and effects. And when I say a lot, I really do mean a lot. If you do not suffer from epilipsy, please, take breaks after an hour of play. I know, I sound like someone who says you should take break after an hour of playing video games, but no. Beat Hazard is a special case. After playing for like 1 hour, I started to have an headache, and plus, my eyes started to feel tired. And I'm not making this up. So please, if you're going to play this excellent game, take care of yourself, and take a break after an hour of consecutive play.Overall, you should buy this game. I highly recommend it. I also recommend that you play with a controller. ;)
