number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Beat Hazard, or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love Particle Effects.Now before anyone reads this, I should mention that Beat Hazard IS ACTUALLY A GOOD GAME, it's  fun and well designed, I just can't reccomend it, personally.Beat Hazard is a victim of great potential, poor execution. I'm not a huge fan of shmups, but when I do play them, being able to have the tempo of the level set to my own music was an idea I was fast enamored with. The game works as advertized, I suppose and it's relatively fun. That should be enough to get it a thumbs up... but I just can't do it. Beat Hazard suffers from a terminal case of a complete lack of gameplay clarity.If you at any point start chatting up a games developer, there is a good chance that at some point, they'll tell you that it's generally a good idea that the player feel responsible for their own failure. If failure in a game is beyond the player's control, they will quickly start to resent the game for it. Failure is rewarding if it gives experience towards doing better next time, but failure in Beat Hazard often comes from not being able to tell if a piece of debris is a particle effect or a broken chunk of dangerous meteorite. Failure comes from being hit by a missile indistinguishable from the sparks coming from your ship, other ships, powerups and even parts of the freaking user interface, which are lit up more flamboyantly than a mardi-gras fireworks show.EDIT: Yes, I did turn down the particle effects in the options menu. It did not help.The biggest letdown to me though, was the fact that the music only really affected the strength of your weapon (and the intensity of the godforsaken particle effects) and not the size and tenacity of the enemy. Enemy ships will probably appear in greater numbers on a 180 bps drumstep track compared to a 40 bps suicide anthem, but the intensity of the song has little to no effect on how fast the enemy moves or what kinds of bad guy appear. The slow spots in any song do slow down the action, and buildups are often oddly quiet which is a nice touch, but it honestly doesn't feel like the track you select makes a noticable difference in the level.In perfect honesty, short of Audio Surf, Beat Hazard is probably one of the better rhythm games out there, due mostly to the fact that it's powered entirely by your own music, and can do so competantly. That being said, I'm not going to reccommend a rotten game just because it's slightly less rotten than everything else in the fridge. Beat Hazard is a pretty standard shoot-em-up that could probably be marketted more successfully as a music visualization program. Imagine playing "Operation" while being shot in both eyes with a rapidly flashing, high intensity laser while in a moving car, with a stereo stuck at 90 dB playing dubstep and you have a pretty solid idea on what Beat Hazard is like.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												"iTunes ain't got nothin' on this!" 5/10Looking for a new way to spice up your music listening sessions? If you answered yes, then this is the game for you! Because 'Beat Hazard' is basically just a music visualizer with lives. And if you don't have enough lives to make it through the song, well, then you don't hear the end of that song; it's as simple as that. Finally something that makes listening to music more challenging! Ugh, we've seen this game a thousand times before, literally, there are a thousand other versions of this game out there already. Like 'Asteroids, Geometry Wars, Darius Twin, Giga Wing, 1943, LifeForce, Gradius, Raiden, Super Stardust, etc. You get the point, there are a lot of spaceship shooty games on the market.Sad to say however, 'Beat Hazard' adds nothing new to this already saturated genre other than allowing us to play along to our favorite songs. But we could already do that by listening to our favorite songs while playing better versions of this game with the sound off. It was a nice attempt but 'Beat Hazard' falls really flat, no pun intended. There is just too much going on visually, even when turning the effects down half-way, and sometimes it's much too difficult to distinguish from what will and will not hurt you as debris flies all about. Not to mention the graphics look very cheap, especially the spaceship, and with a game with so many visual effects, it seriously hinders the experience, at least for me.Overall there is still some fun to be had here, but pick 'Beat Hazard' up on sale, because ten bucks is just too much to pay for this generic pile of visual poppycock. The 'Survival Mode' is the one aspect that may keep you coming back, but other than that, avoid this game for something better like one of the titles mentioned above, because honestly, the one thing this game promises to do; power itself with your music, it doesn't even do very well.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I personally found this game... underwhelming.The issue stems from what the game promises, or seemingly hopes, to deliver to the user. A radically fun experience powered by your own music. The description of the game made me hope to have a racing and heart-pounding experience much like audiosurf, but it felt more like drinking a Red Bull compared to doing cocaine.To put it bluntly, Beat Hazard is a space shooter. Your lazers, the enemies spawn points, and their flight patterns, are all dictated by your music. You only have about 2 powerups that just change the potency of your weapons, and the volume of your music. You collect money, which is used to buy and upgrade perks, that only increase your score and nothing else. You 'rank up', a leveling system, based on your scores from the songs you've played, but don't get much out of it.All in all, Beat Hazard is a seizure-enducing, messy, and underwhelming experience. Only electronic music could really fit the game's theme, and the game by itself is entirely obsolete without the DLC. And even THAT is obsolete thanks to Beat Hazard Ultra. The game encourages you to create it's steam badges to get new ships that are only minor changes, and a majority of the fun features isn't available without Shadow Operations Unit DLC.The game is fun for a length of maybe 15 minutes, while the player holds the mouse button and waits for the level to be beat. The enemies may as well be made of clay, the lights and particles blinding the entire screen, and the explosions even less exciting. Beat Hazard is like taking ecstacy only to be immune to it after it wears off forever.Going back to Audiosurf.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												If I had to chose just one word for this game it would be 'cluttered'.  Even with the visual effects turned down to the lowest you still can't see what going on.  Every explosion ends up just obscuring the screen so you can't see anything, worse is the level's music makes these unnecessary effects even more flashy and annoying.  You'll die more often than not to bullets or foes that where hidden by these effects. If they could be turn them off this game would have no challenge what so ever.Speaking of the music, this game's soundtrack is standard issue techno crap, it sounds like it came right out of 2003.  The whole thing where your own tracks make new levels, that sucks too.  The only think music determines is how much of the screen you can't see.  I have notice that the enemy waves follow the same pattern if you use the same song, so it does have some factor but  couldn't tell you how it works.  Every time I tried one of my own tracks what happened on the screen didn't match the beat or tone or anything at all.  Hell, half the songs I tried had absolutely nothing was going screen for 10-15 seconds.Doesn't waste you money on this game, get a real bullet storm game, like Ikaruga.

number of helpful: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Beat Hazard is a game that's primarily flash and relatively little substance. The main gimmick, the music detection, only really results in three distinct modes: During very quiet sections, very slow enemies pile up on the sides while you struggle to do any damage to them. Otherwise the various technicolor explosions, blur effects, and strobing lights constantly going off only range from "excessive" to "blinding", even with effects turned to the minimum setting. Enemy fire tries to stand out against the visual barrage, but mostly fails to do so. Smartbombs are used not when you are about to get hit, but instead when you can't tell if you're going to get hit or not. The game then follows this up by encouraging you to grind perks for more smartbombs to fight the Excessively Flashy Bright Menace with your own excessive flashy brightness.I recommend Assault Android Cactus instead for your twinstick shooter fix.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Bah. No wonder I haven't played this game in so long, or very much. I love music, and this was supposed to be a awesome way to get immersed into a game with your music. It gets a big "No, it's doesn't" from me. With the other noises going on, it's a huge distraction from what using your own music in this is supposed to do. The single worst thing that enflames that aspect though, is the volume power-ups. So, even if you start out with something huge and blasting, well, too bad. It's going to play it softly until you collect the power-ups to make it louder so that you can actually hear the music that you put on. On top of that, it often doesn't matter , since sometimes when you blow something up, it dips the volume for a bit anyway, as if it needed some kind of sidechain compression between the music and game audio for some reason. Completely breaks the immersive experience, and so the game just comes along as feeling cheap and gimmicky. Especially since, without the music hook, there's nothing that makes the game stand out. Go buy Audiosurf. It's also very simplistic, but if your looking for a game where using your own music actually adds something to the experience: It's much better.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I've tried giving this game a chance 2 times now. To me it's just a visualizer software that reacts to the music with merely particle effects. I would have wanted the enemy patterns be spawned in sync with the beat to make the game feel more reactive to your music (Tried different genres: metal, house, techno, ambient). Right now it just feels that the music and gameplay are in completely different layers and that doesn't work for me.One could argue that there is some spawns reacting to the music but it doesn't feel that way. Often times you get bored and frustated when you start thinking all the things the game could have been. The spawns are too vague and unresponsive. I feel the main intent in design was to analyze the song length, create some sort of an enemy buildup into that timeframe and then spawn enemies with an intensifying interval towards the end. It's not a really elaborate system but a really generalized one.  It doesn't feel reactive to the music or feel particularly interesting.Here are a few examples that I wanted to see: *Having the enemy sprites pulse to the beat at times and giving you extra stuff if destroyed in a swollen state.*Having different enemy types pulse to different beats in the music.*Having certain archtypes of beat sequences built to the system. For example in house music the rythm, buildup and lead are quite predictable, those could be used as standardized information and made into gameplay events.*Every hi-hat spawning a small single enemy from a corner starting from top left and ending in bottom right.*Every bass hit it could spawn a round pattern of small popcorn enemies etc. Maybe if the core gameplay were more engaging, I would not have cared about enemy beat sync, meaning the lack thereof, that much. Right now I don't feel like it really holds it's own though. It feels there are many enemy archtypes that could be used to make the gameplay more engaging and less predictable.Also the enemy sprites look clumbsy and lack animation which gives me a somewhat unfinished feeling while playing. They stick out.To me this game was not enjoyable due to lack of polish and expectations not being met.

												Wow what a turd don't read this don't play this game ZERO STARS REVIEWBeat Hazards is a game that takes every chance it gets to insult and talk down to the player. It puts the old adage “show, don’t tell” to work by by showing your eye ball sockets what it’s like to be brutally violated. This is not a vulgar and childish joke, I mean violate in the strict dictionary definition. The game shows clear disrespect for and oversteps the bounds of the players’ eyes. Even aside from the eyes, the game gives the player no quarter and from the boot up pumps the player’s BOSE headphones full of fat Jams. You would expect Jams to play an integral role in the “gameplay” (more on this later) but instead they react more to the menu.The menu is outright impossible to behold. I mean this in the worst sense possible. A player may start up Beat H. expecting to see beats or hazard in a visual feast for the eyes and is instead subjected to a visual assault. The ‘feast’ is turned up to a prepaid buffet where the player is forced to consume far more than is reasonable in order to make the bill seem worth it. I’m saying that the menus are a horrible and traumatizing experience. The player is encouraged to get away from the title menu and dive right into the “gameplay” only to make it stop. By reducing the visuals option slider the figurative laser pointer goes from green to red, but still isn’t something I would point at an eye.The gameplay in Beat El Hazzard is Asteroids in a pretty dress with an okay wig but she still smells like cigarettes and hey your drivers license says you’re older than my parents. #1reasonwhyIn summary the gameplay is something I have seem a million times before. S.P.A.Z. did not cause me real life pain from playing so it could be the TOP DOG Asteroids clone in the stunky oniondustry. Sometimes all you need is a jam and a space ship to shoot the rocks and UFOs. However WE are not so simple-minded. It is telling that the metacritic score for the title is a 404 error.Has:- Last.FM support. Get social! - Enjoy from your home theater with BOSE digital headphones!- Twitter & Leaderboard support. Your friends care about you.Lacks:- The Vampire’s Curse- Living, Breathing World- Gameplay ElementZERO stars sorry but this is an inferior product I can’t tell you to buy this like I can BOSE professional grade audio equipment for the home audio enthusiast-- The Sharper ImageLet’s much out the competition!Famitsu: 1/10: Too easy, piece of cake! -- How are you guys not Kotaku?Shounen Jump: 5/10 THIS GAME IN SPACE HAS GUTS! -- Yeah like YOU made a game??Xplay: Three.... out of Five. -- Adam SISSY Why anyone would give Beet Hazz more than a star is beyond meIGN: “I forgot to do the homework sir. I didn’t play it.” -- Yeah my man let’s meet up & do some shots at MacWorld! #shotsIf you like this review please “share” it with your Facebook and Twitter social contacts. Please subscribe to our catalog magazine we really need the money.

												NOT RECOMMENDED.  This is an awful game.  Beat Hazard is completely unplayable with any music that isn't normalized to high amplitude all the time because the♥♥♥♥♥♥that comes out of your guns is directly proportional to how active the music is.  You'll be doing well and then all of a sudden it's like someone just turned the valve on your faucet; little sputters come out in place of the usual soundless streams of color, and you are just ♥♥♥♥ed.It's also impossible to even see what's going on.  The game tries so hard to be extreme that it just peppers the entire screen with identically colored glittery flashy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that prevents you from seeing enemy bullets.  I hate the scoring system, too.  Oh, and the whole enterprise is phenomenally ugly, just a bunch of samey cardboard cutouts.  Even the swooshy menus♥♥♥♥♥♥me off.The fact that Beat Hazard has been a success seems to say something dire about how susceptible people are to the music generation gimmick.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2011
												Beat hazard is a very simple game. You play as a tiny space ship in deep space; you float around the screen shooting lasers at unsuspecting asteroids and ships. This game is basically plays exactly like the classic game Asteroids. The art style is very fitting for the game, with song beats as soon as you enter the main menu of the game. Sadly people with chronic epilepsy cannot play this game. The flashing colors might actually kill them; in fact it almost killed me. I have a massive headache after getting all my achievements. This game’s replayability value is similar to that of Audio Surf, it’s totally dependent on whether or not you have anything better to do.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This game is trying to combine a 'bullet-hell' arcade shooter with a game that reacts to and changes with a chosen music file, and honestly, it is mediocre at both.  A few specific examples of things I don't like about the game:- When you die, your ship drops a number of powerups.  There have been many times where I've died early in a level, and ended up better off for it because of the drops (I've even had my score multiplier increase after dying).- The levels are randomly generated, even with the same song, so high scores per song are basically meaningless.- As far as I can tell, the only way the game 'reacts' to your music is by slowing down the enemies and your fire-rate (and weakening your weapons it seems) during slow or quiet parts of songs.  A major downside of this, is that for songs that are slow and/or quiet by nature, it is nearly impossible to kill anything because your bullets are so weak and shoot so slowly.- A side note, if you don't like games with excessively bright and flashing lights, do NOT buy this game.  I have the visual intensity set to 25% and it is still a seizure on the screen.All that said, if you want an arcade shooter whose soundtrack is your own music library, then this is the game for you.  Although you'd be better off buying a real bullet-hell game, muting the game's music, and playing your own.  If you want a game that generates levels based off of your music tracks, then check out Audiosurf.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
   Overview   Beat Hazard (Ultra) is a music-based game that centers around music, primarily your own playlists, often via iTunes or other media libraries. The game itself has you piloting a ship (or one of many with DLC) whose goal is to score as many points as necessary within the length of any given song and to avoid dying. You'll face enemies ranging from stray asteroids and basic enemy ships, to mines and even bosses in the form of large monsters or battleships with a multitude of weapons at their disposal. The game rewards you for staying alive by supplying you random powerups and score multipliers that dropped from defeated enemies. If you die, which you can by being hit just once, you lose some  of your powers and score bonuses. At the end of the song, your score is tallied and as you score more points, your piloting rank will increase. Increasing your rank gives you the option to select bonus perks, weapons or even extra lives based on your play style.The difficulty can be adjusted based on two parameters: The song you play and the base game's difficulty. Since the game's pace is based on your music's pace, speeding up and slowing down as the music does, creating a different play through for each song. You can also ramp up the challenge by selecting "hardcore", "insane" "and suicidal". I found "hardcore" to be a nice base for causal playing if you're looking for something that won't stress you out. "Insane" is great for a challenge and "Suicidal" is, well, suicidal. If you're looking to test your reflexes, it will show you no mercy. In my eyes, the visuals are what make this game so enjoyable. Even with roughly 40 hours of game play done at the time of this review, the visuals have yet to bore me. The visuals, much like the pace of the game, will fluctuate between slow and erratic, constantly changing colors. Players can adjust how strong they want the color effects from the ingame menu, helpful for those with sensitivity issues or that have a difficult time determining enemies from balls of light in the background. While your overall enjoyment and replayability may differ, the game is well polished and provides comfortable atmosphere and challenging game play. I've enjoyed every moment of this game.    Pros    Music - The game syncs to your media library, offering you as many songs to play against as you have. Track Diversity - The waves of enemies you meet and the pace you meet them changes on each track, keeping you on your toes. Visuals - Colorful, bright (sometimes too bright :P) and, frankly, pretty to watch.Challenge - The game can offer a constant challenge.    Cons    Without music on your PC, the game would be a shell of its former self. Aside from internet radio and a few built-in tracks, you'll not find much fun after a few play throughs. Having your own music is highly recommended. Overall, if you're a fan of music-based games, then I'd highly recommend looking into Beat Hazard.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 21, 2011
												Beat Hazard is a fun twin stick shooter where you select a track from your music library as your level selection.  While playing, you'll hear the track you selected and the enemy waves will be generated based on what you're hearing.  It happens in such a way that a given track will always play the same, allowing you to learn and get better at a specific track.The graphics are great, and the gamepad controls are perfect.  If you don't have a gamepad, you can attempt to make due with mouse and keyboard controls.Beat Hazard is also the only game I'm aware of that has in-game rewards for crafting its Steam badge.  You unlock a ship skin with the level 1 badge, the level 5 badge, and the foil badge.  These ship skins are purely aesthetic changes, though the width of the firing pattern does vary slightly between them.DLC:Beat Hazard Ultra completely transforms the game and makes it better in every way, adding more enemies, more bosses, and a perk system, as well as making enemy waves far less predictable.  Highly recommended.iTunes and m4a support is only necessary if you have music in these formats that you want to play.  Otherwise, you can ignore this DLC entirely.Shadow Operations Unit adds extra ships to the game with different stats and their own separate leaderboards, and Steam Workshop support for creating and sharing your own ships.  Each ship also has a set of missions (read: challenges) to complete.  Highly recommended.

												Beat Hazard is a glorious epileptic seizure inducing  ballet with spaceships, lasers, missiles, bosses, and space junk all waiting to be destroyed to the soundtrack of your choosing. Each level is configured around the song that you choose to play it to. The music list is limitless, because you are able to use music from your PC, the Beat Hazard soundtrack, and internet radio. I bought this game when it first came to Xbox Live Arcade and I was ecstatic that it was brought to PC. This is one game that I can sink a few minutes or an hour into simply because I can listen to great music while doing so! I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of playing their own soundtrack in a game.

												This game is simply mental. Probably still one of the best music-enhanced arcade games on the market. It's ridiculously tough to play along to good music, but manages to remain simultaneously fun and constantly heart-attack inducing. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 18, 2010
												This is a game that is driven by your music. At first, it will take some getting use to the intense lights which make it hard to distinguish enemies and their fire. You'll soon find yourself immersed in the music and the more intense the music, the more powerful your ship's fire power! Don't worry if the only tracks you have on your computer are from Barney's Soundtrack (although the 'I Love You, You Love Me' song is surprisingly intense), Beat Hazard provides a nice sampling of music to play with.There are survival and 'chillout' modes, in addition to track by track play. The game rewards you via a ranking system so the more you play, the more points you score, the higher up the ranks you'll go. Ranks earn you bonuses in-game, giving you better starting stats, better score multipliers and more ways to stay alive.Putting all epilepsy jokes aside (no seriously, don't play if you are prone to seizures) this music+arcade shooter game will have you mesmerized from the start!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												This game has about a dozen serious flaws and countless minor ones. Being completely blasted by neon rainbows any time you do just about anything will probably make you want to rip your eyes out halfway through your first song. Even if it doesn't, there's basically no way to see any important information on the screen, like small ships and hazardous debris. More than half the time I die, it's not because I failed to dodge a bullet or enemy, but is instead because of something that I never saw at all.Power-ups will appear for a short duration, but the warning that they are about to disappear might as well not have been bothered being added given it's lack of usefulness. By the time they start to blink, unless you're practically on top of them already, there is no way you could possibly make it to pick them up anyways. This happens extremely frequently given that they drop randomly from enemies, and the enemies will frequently appear in extremely long strings from off screen. As a result, the enemies you kill will drop power-ups you can't reach because they are obstructed by other enemies.The stream of enemies from off screen is also frustrating, as like many top-down shooters in a box, enemies can appear from off screen right where you are without warning. As a result, you are really restricted to an even smaller play area unless you'd like to risk rage and frustration.Song volume seems to be a cosmetic power-up with no tangible effect in game. Added to the lack of significant differences between enemy appearance (there are about 5 non-bosses, with 3 beings practically identical), the game feels like it suffers from a shocking shortage of creativity. All in all, I highly recommend you avoid buying this game. Despite liking this style of game (both top-down arcade shooters and dynamic music driven games) I feel like I wasted my money even though I picked it up for just a few dollars during a sale.

												A really enjoyable bullet hell twin stick shooter. The music aspect basically comes down to everything speeding up when the music gets louder, and slowing down when the music gets softer, but the gameplay itself is solid. I've bought this game on both iOS and Steam, and both are excellent, although I prefer the Steam one as the virtual sticks on the iOS version can occasionally get frustrating to use. My biggest issue is the amount of potentially seizure-inducing flashing lights in the game by default, but thankfully you can turn down the visual intensity.8/10 So nice I bought it twice

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												What's better than a Arcade Style Twin-Stick Shoot 'em up? The soundtrack that gets you pumped up in the game. This is one game that people who enjoy games and music should own. You'll never be "done" with this game, because your music makes the levels, and your high-scores are for each track. That means as long as you keep getting music, you keep getting more to do with this game. Then there is also the multiplayer co-op, versus, online, survival, and boss rush modes and many more options and perks (<- no really, you unlock perks), that keep the game interesting and challenging. Also makes for a nice background if you are into throwing parties with flashing lights and colors.

												The ability to put your music into a game and have it generate something out of the data it receives is nothing new.  However, having it actually create something awesome may very well be.  This arena shooter can range from mild to ballistic in terms of difficulty, and the methods in which the mobs and shots are spawned can be strangely accurate to the music playing.  One bizarre occasion, I was playing "Army of Me - Bjork" and near the entire level was just masses and masses of insignificant small mobs, which more or less describes what the song is about.  (piddly little problems that aren't enough to take me down) Stuff like this and the pheonomenal visuals make this worth anyone's time.  X360 controller very recommended.

The game is absolutely fantastic, and if you have any taste and decency, you'll add it to your wish list at once. It's a bit like Audiosurf in that it uses your own music library to craft a game, but rather than a weird puzzle game, it's a visually stunning shmup that gets more and more crazy as you pump up the volume. Seriously fun stuff.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 21, 2011
												Beat Hazard is a fun twin stick shooter where you select a track from your music library as your level selection.  While playing, you'll hear the track you selected and the enemy waves will be generated based on what you're hearing.  It happens in such a way that a given track will always play the same, allowing you to learn and get better at a specific track.The graphics are great, and the gamepad controls are perfect.  If you don't have a gamepad, you can attempt to make due with mouse and keyboard controls.Beat Hazard is also the only game I'm aware of that has in-game rewards for crafting its Steam badge.  You unlock a ship skin with the level 1 badge, the level 5 badge, and the foil badge.  These ship skins are purely aesthetic changes, though the width of the firing pattern does vary slightly between them.DLC:Beat Hazard Ultra completely transforms the game and makes it better in every way, adding more enemies, more bosses, and a perk system, as well as making enemy waves far less predictable.  Highly recommended.iTunes and m4a support is only necessary if you have music in these formats that you want to play.  Otherwise, you can ignore this DLC entirely.Shadow Operations Unit adds extra ships to the game with different stats and their own separate leaderboards, and Steam Workshop support for creating and sharing your own ships.  Each ship also has a set of missions (read: challenges) to complete.  Highly recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 7, 2011
												Beat Hazard is a arena dual stick shooter or arena shump if you prefer; mind you seeing how it's for PC is more or less keyboard and mouse shooter but don't let that take away from what this game actually is or dose.Graphically this game isn't anything special (let’s be honest this isn't the reason why you play it) it's the visuals; oh the visuals are just amazing due to it being a "visualizer" it does just that. Remember Apple's and Microsoft’s visualizer or maybe you're one of those people that still put that on. What IF you wanted to play a game in that cluster f***? Well you can!Controls (I personally like the keyboard and mouse so I mostly know them) are smooth and responsive as hell, the keyboard controls the ship and abilities, the mouse fires and also uses abilities; they're fully bindable. The controller plays just as you expect, one control stick controls the ship and the other fires in the direction, the abilities are used with the triggers (I think).The gameplay is well... you’re put in an arena; you listen to your music AND YOU SHOOT EVERYTHING AND EVERYONE UNTIL YOU GO BLIND or YOU DIE. Sounds simple enough, well it's just that honestly. Depending upon the song this can be easy as hell or so hard you just wanna kill someone! The online is a bit weak due to "you must have the same copy of the song" due to piracy; co-op isn't bad; I only really played an hour on co-op.While the game is fun and awesome there are some things that just fall flat on its face. The fact that Ultra is DLC; this isn’t a bad thing but compared to the original the Ultra DLC offers WAY more in content and gameplay, I’m not saying the original isn’t fun but it comes across kind of lame in comparison… at least for me, there are quite a bit of people who just like the original more. Once you beat the game, level to the highest level and get all of the achievements it offers very little to come back to. Some bullets are VERY hard to see considering what it is and that’s the point but sometimes you’ll be wondering what just killed you!? The games difficulty is great and all but it also leads to certain songs being balls hard while some easy as hell.This game is one of my favorite music based games and it’s completely fun but it offers no reliability or even an incentive to even come back to, some may find that not such a big deal considering the price of the game but once you’re done… you’re actually done… of course there is a leaderboard so… there’s that I guess. The visuals are great but can lead to mystery deaths. Songs can be way too hard or way too easy, sometimes you can’t find a middle ground. Is the game worth it? Yes, but I love music and at times play games with my music. This game really depends if you can stand a lot of visuals, love music.(My first review)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 19, 2011
												If you're a fan of either music games or twitch arcade shooters you'll probably love Beat Hazard.The mechanics are esentially a homage to the classic arcade Asteroids... except made completely insane by more visual stimuli than the human eye can probably process. The real hook of the game though is that every level is generated by whatever music track you've selected. It's easy to zone out as you steer your little ship through bullet hell while jamming along to whatever it is you fill your iDevice with.Bottom line is that the game is fun as hell. And it's replay value is roughly whatever the size of your music collection is (although the included tracks are actually quite good). Just be aware of the photosensitive warning at the game's start. This game isn't messing aorund. There will be colors flying everywhere constantly.And did I mention this game was made by just one man? Indie game win.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2011
												As a game that uses lots of strobe effects and tons of objects, it looks like a turnoff and a headache. But going deeper in this game, it is actually a very fun ship shooter experience. The usage of music is nice by using changes in intensity, which the game encourages by putting Volume powerups to increase the music volume. The enemy types are varied well, from asteroids to dummy ships to more interesting tentacles and gunships. Each enemy is weak or very powerful and able to deal massive damage. The music not only afffects weapon powerups but subtly the light intensity and enemy speed. This game's built in collection of music is a more hardcore experience best suited for the gameplay, but using your own music is also in itself very fun. Certain songs can be funny and give unexpected results or a good song for a game.Though the graphics might be too much for some people, Beat Hazard combines addictive space shooting with the power of users' music.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Quick pros and cons rundown-+Works with any song (within a number of formats) fairly well.+Seizures+lazers (right?)+easy ship customization (DLC)+replayability, good to pass time+visually pretty spectacular+works with replay gain-DLC's should be free-I wish at times it didn't go through the included music.-Don't turn up your volume on the first level-More perks that are harder to get-visual theme (menus) could be packaged a little cleaner-no linux icon (not a big problem, but it'd be nice to have)I've played this game for about an hour now, and so far I'm really liking it. At first I didn't get why there was no music on the first game, and then I got VOL's and nearly shattered my eardrums, it's a first time thing, but I think there could at least be a first-time warning. I also began to realize that my music was being drowned out by explosions and gunfire, which can be turned off, but I think they're a bit much to begin with. There are some cool options, my entire library works perfectly (with replay gain, that's definitely a big plus), and this game is definitely worthy of the seizure warning on the front, if you haven't already gathered that. I think this game would be pretty good for passing the time, especially after you get a new album or something. Thing is, I got the entire bundle on slae for $5, and while this is a great game, I would pay the $10, but I really think that should inculde the shadow ops stuff and the ultra stuff as well. The ship creator that comes with shadow ops is very intuitive from what I've seen (I haven't made anything yet), but it looks like you can upload any image and tweak the stats to your liking. Issue being, again, I think that should be built into the game rather than DLC. Visually the game is fantastic, but I think the whole theme could be wrapped together a little nicer, as it's a little all-over-the-place. In game it looks very nice, and I LOVE how the clouds and stars pulse to the music: that aspect is perfect. What isn't perfect is that the enemies don't sync into the music as good as they could, and it seems like, in comparison, Symphony does a bit of a better job, but I've only seen videos, so I can't confirm that. The perks system is cool, but I think there could be more, as your selection is kind of limited, and I also flew through a ton of ranks really quickly (and I'm not super good), so maybe those should be harder to get. Also, it will randomly go through the included music in the menu, which I think isn't.. exactly... adequate.... Overall I think it's a neat casual-to-hardcore game with some great replayability and a price that could come down just a bit.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												 - PROS -I got absolutely stunned by all the flashing lights, the colors and the music that was already in the game, it is your own personal Rave Party ( without the girls ;) ) You open the game it has the warning about the visual effects and it's generally addiciting and fun aswell as being able to upload the songs and even challenge a friend on your favorite tracks. It's pretty well optimized and doesn't require anything. It is just as noobfriendly as it is challenging for some Counter-Striker Swedish E-sport player. - CONS - The game's effects is both a blessing and a curse, the curse about it is when it actually gets in the way if you put it on too high % of the effects. The game can also slowdown if you have too much stuff on the screen if you're using a lower PC-Rig.I am also gonna note that be careful when you're using a controller because at one point I had the controller in and put it out and the game just flipped out and was on the xbox controller menu like you constantly pressed the A button aswell as going down in the menu automaticly, maybe it is my controller config but that's a warning nonetheless.- CONCLUSION -Overall the problems with the controllers are gone and it's definetly a fun and amazing game to try out if you're just bored and want to listen to music. Do not play this if you have a confirmed epilepsi. I had Epilepsi when I was a child but it is gone for me but that's a good advice. It's a great game and its worth a shot and grab Ultra while you're at it. Worth every penny.VIII of X  Pyros!

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This game for me was quite a surprise, a great surprise.  I do not normally play these types of games, but this game to me feels like a mix of the old Atari game Asteroids mixed with the music you normally listen to.  On top of that, it is like Asteroids on steroids.  At first I never thought I would be able to complete a mission on Hardcore, but as time went on my skill improved and I recently finished a mission on Suicidal.  This is one of the most fun, addictive games I have ever played and I am so happy I found it.This game has several difficulties, perks that you choose to help you defeat the enemy, different ships you can select which have different fire patterns, speeds, inertia.  This game is so challenging on so many different levels, add in your own music and it is simply one of the best games ever.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												This game may be simple, but it is one of the few games that I have never played the same way twice. You have as much freedom as you could possiblyneed, since it is powered by your own music library. Not only is it visually impressive, but the levels of difficulty are greatly matched to give you a wide spectrum of options. Most of the fun comes from creating your own challenges and goals. Try going as long as you can without firing your weapon, or only move your ship to the beat of the music, things like that.This game is fun by yourself, but also has great party game potential. Plus it into the living room sound system, and you got music and entertainment covered

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Beat Hazard is quite the interesting game. It offers some rapid-fire shmup action combined with multicolored flashing lights and the ability to integrate your own music library. Altogether, it offers a fast paced, ever changing audiovisual experience.Yes, the game has its flaws. Gameplay is rather straightforward, and there is not much offered by music integration, aside from some frustration when calm sections result in an extremely weak ship. For many people, the visual effects are too distracting, and in some cases, can cause aching eyes or seizures.Beat Hazard is not for everyone, particularly those uninterested in shmups and those with epilepsy or similar physical handicaps related to flashing lights. And if your music library is entirely composed of ballads and lullabies? You should definitely avoid this game, or at least think twice about purchasing it before you tire of the games included music selections. However, if you enjoy rapid space stick shooters, have a fancy for light shows, and/or own a decently sized collection of upbeat or high-energy music, then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Very fun game when you're just wanting to chill and listen to some tunes.While playing I noticed that when there are heavy base elements (drums and the like) little tiny explosions of color go off all over the screen. This is where things got ugly. I decided, "Hey, I'll play some Metallica!" I browsed through my media and landed upon Death Magnetic (an album known for how incredibly loud Lars' drums are). I put on "All Nightmare Long" and set it for normal mode with 100% visuals. During a large boss encounter Lars' drums sounded with a bang, and before I knew it I was englufed into a sea of beautiful explosions, then I died from a seizure. I am dead now, God let me use his PC to type this review in the hopes that lives can be saved. DO NOT, I repeat, DO NOT play any tracks from Death Magnetic with 100% visuals, you will die.

												Only have a couple of hours but boy I was not expecting it to be this fun. On sale for $1.99? Awesome grab. It's your average space old-school shooter game combined with INSANE visual effects that go with YOUR music. ANY song, reads its bpm's, peaks and lows and then manages it to put into a unique, fast-paced action shooter. The enemies move according to the song, the pace goes along with the song, your shooting style goes along with the song - everything in a perfect and beautiful sync. The game is never ending since you can play it with any song on your computer - and every run is different. JUST BUY IT10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												This game is on sale right now (6/26/14) and you should probably buy it. Or any time in the future it comes on sale. I haven't had this much fun with a random purchase sale game since Anomaly, and boy is it worth it. Don't rock the epilepsy and I'm sure you'll have a blast with this game, either included music or your own. You don't need to play it with just your standard electro pop that you think might be most appropriate, one of my most frentic games was when I played Home by Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeroes. There is a fair amount of skill involved, and you'll need to heighten your spatial awareness to pay attention to what's going on (one of the DLC's includes an option to downgrade the visual effects, if you're that kind of person). There's even a persistent upgrade system and missions and leaderboards and online play (which I haven't tried yet) and local multiplayer (which I also haven't tried yet). It's a fun♥♥♥♥♥bundle of a cheap game that'll rock for you if you've got music on your computer, or want to rediscover the music that's already there. I can't recommend this game enough, there's so much to it. I'd like to think that if you projected it on a screen at a dance party it'd be a ♥♥♥♥ing blast. It's beyond competent and extremely colorful, a great break from whatever dark gritty open world zombie survival crafting game I'm sure you've been playing recently. 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2011
												Pretty awesome rhythm-based game, where the songs on your own hard drive determine your gameplay experience.  Anyone familiar with Audiosurf or Rhythm Zone should understand the concept.  What you get with Beat Hazard is essentially a really fun, effective mix of Asteroids and Audiosurf, complete with great, vibrant graphics, high replayability, and fun gameplay.  Each song you play will generate a different experience, with your guns and the enemies getting stronger and quicker as the song gets faster and more intense, and will also generate boss fights randomly throughout.Beat Hazard comes with single player, two-player, online co-op and competitive multiplayer, and lots of perks (upgrades) you can equip in your ship's slots, tailoring the game to your style.  Really enjoyable game overall, and worth it if you have lots of songs on  your computer.  There's a demo on Steam, so check it out!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												As a Bullet Hell Shooter, it's one of the smoothest I've played, and doing it to my music is really fun. However, the ultimate 'thumbs down', however tentative (consider this a 6/10), is because the game pisses me off so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ much.Mainly it's the Shadow Missions; they're just way too unforgiving. As in, 'you will probably wake up covered in someone's blood' levels of unforgiving. Say, for example, a Shadow Mission saying "Beat 3 Songs on Insane Difficulty." Fine.Songs only count if they're 3:30+ long. Fine.If you die ONCE during this song (considering you have like 5 lives from the outset so if you're any good you should seldom fail a mission) it won't count towards your mission progress.This is where you're gonna get angry. REALLY angry. You could get to the last 10 seconds of a song and die to a missile you couldn't see due to the game's patented Seizure-o-vision, and the game will flip you the bird and your time will have been wasted. If it was an instant game over when you died, it would be a bit more bearable, but as it is? You're gonna swear, you're gonna break stuff, you're gonna fantasize about meeting the people who designed these missions and kicking them repeatedly in the crotch.Back to the topic of the flashing lights, I started getting a headache within SECONDS of hitting the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed MAIN MENU. The photosensitive seizure warning at the start doesn't do justice to just how much eyestrain you're gonna experience. On top of that, the obnoxious flashing lights make it near impossible to see the, say, red glowing seeker mines or the tiny missiles that'll kill you and give a solid 'F U' to your current Shadow Mission.I'm perfectly fine with games being difficult, so long as they're FAIR. Super Meat Boy is fair. Dark Souls is fair. In both of those games, when you die, it's YOUR FAULT. Here, though, you could die to something you couldn't even SEE through the flashing lights, and the game will essentially kneecap you.I'm sorry but, for whatever fun I was having, I'm more likely to remember my foaming rage than I am to remember any enjoyment.

												Beat Hazard is one of those twin-stick shooters that you can have a literal "blast" with your music.  While the controls works best with a controller, they're still solid with a mouse & keyboard.The difficulty with the game & the stages vary based on how you equip your ship with power-ups, items & unlockables.  This really makes it easy to play the game with your music.  If you don't have a great music library on hand OR want something completely different, tap into an online radio station & play with whatever they happen to be broadcasting (one way to keep you on your toes)!While the DLC is mostly optional, I do recommend picking it up for the best experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 14, 2013
												Two-stick-shooter, score multipliers, power-ups...visually disorienting...I've heard it described as "Asteroids on acid". I cannot disagree with that.Reminds me of my days as an arcade-rat. In a good way.I've tried Beat Hazard with speed metal, hardcore punk, various electronic stuff, Beatles, Pink Floyd, Black Sabbath, African trance drumming, "new age" stuff, comedy songs, 70-80's pop (Loverboy, KISS etc.) and some classical.Custom level for every piece of music, yet the same level every time you play that tune. ♥♥♥♥ing brilliant algorithm, really. It's interesting to see how it interprets songs.A slow, yet sonically rich, piece will yield as much of a challenge as a high-speed-blitz kind of song, just...different.Motorhead? Sigur Ros? Duran Duran? Yes.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Of all the games that use your music library to create a stage to play on, Beat Hazard tops the list.  It's not just a simple platformer or racing game like the others, but it is instead a side-scrolling shooter where your enemies, their strength, and your power-ups are determined by the songs you play.Combine this with good support for multiple file types and internet radio, and you've got a fun casual game that uses music really well for some dynamic gameplay.  Pick this game up if you want a fun side-scrolling shooter to play with your music!
